That's a slightly different approach from the one I suggested of energy in a system, but it's an empirical definition that exists independently of the scale used to measure it.
I think what you're getting at is that this is a property that cannot be measured directly - that's different from saying it doesn't exist. You must see that it is problematic to say the thermometer is the temperature, when different thermometers operate in different ways and give different results. It would be more usual to say that temperature is always expressed in a temperature scale, derived from the thermometric properties of a second material, and it is this being measured rather than temperature directly. That doesn't mean there is some magic identity between the thermometric variable and the temperature - it's just something that responds in a predictable way to temperature. Like oxygen isotopes in snow. "There is no way to measure temperature directly." (The Physics Hypertextbook).
This still seems to be a largely semantic issue, and I'm no clearer why you think some thermometric properties can be measured while others cannot, nor why you would not believe a photo of a thermometer. I don't know what you are getting at by "One would expect a science so concerned with temperature to be a little more rigorous with temperature scales and its measurement". Who is not concerned? In what way does that impact the science? I don't see what you're saying at all. If you want to say why they're wrong you'd be better doing that than debating the nature of temperature. 
BQSTART
You gave the example of ice core isotope concentrations. Yes, undoubtebly they will vary with temperature, but how? Linearly? Exponentially? by the square power? And is temperature the only variable that the concentration varies with?
BQEND
Do you really think no-one has considered this? Perhaps you think they just assume it's linear? I'm all for challenging science if it's done intelligently. But honestly I don't see how this is better than saying "geneticists - huh they think they're so clever, but how do genes pass information? Write letters to each other?".
It beggars belief that you could have any genuine sense of enquiry and not either assume this issue has been explored, or take the moments it would need to answer it yourself. But - assuming good faith - see the explanation at NASA's site, or look up the Meteoric Water Line. Yes there are challenges. There are challenges in any temperature measurement. You need to show that the response to the challenges is inadequate. You don't even consider it.Scepticism isn't asking questions. Transition time is now here, there’s an atmosphere to save, every minute counts.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1551312361000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16710744', u'in_reply_to': u'126332102', u'id': u'126366493', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VettelCrashes', u'text': u'"I think I would slightly quibble with your definition of temperature; that looks more like a definition of Kelvin - for example how does that definition sit with the temperature of a solid?"
A definition of a physical quantity has to be something you can measure. There is little point in defining temperature from the mean translational (in a gas) or vibrational (in a solid) kinetic energy of molecules, it would be impossible to measure. Kelvin actually is temperature, not a measure of it. Any 1st year undergraduate physics text will tell you.
Quoting Celsius temperature implies that you have first measured Kelvin temp. on the CV gas thermometer. Celsius is defined as Kelvin temp. minus 273.15 (the ice point of water), meaning water freezes at 0.01°C.
All other thermometers use the Centigrade scale. This assumes linear variation of the thermometric property and agrees with the Celsius scale at 0 and 100, but may not for intermediate temperatures. There is a different centigrade scale for each individual thermometer. They will nearly agree, but never totally.
One would expect a science so concerned with temperature to be a little more rigorous with temperature scales and its measurement.
You gave the example of ice core isotope concentrations. Yes, undoubtebly they will vary with temperature, but how? Linearly? Exponentially? by the square power? It’s still early but I don’t know any other candidate that would.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1551293266000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17776092', u'in_reply_to': u'126305054', u'id': u'126359436', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NoMoreMrNice', u'text': u'I think I would slightly quibble with your definition of temperature; that looks more like a definition of Kelvin - for example how does that definition sit with the temperature of a solid? There is a relatively straightforward definition of temperature - the internal energy of a system. The problem is it can't be measured directly; perhaps that's what you mean and we're just arguing semantics. But if your view is right, how can a thermometer be temperature, if what it is showing is how a liquid expands with heat? or resistance in a wire increases, or the isotopic mix of oxygen in snow changes? None of those are temperature; they are all, as you say, thermometric properties that are useful because they change proportionally to temperature. 
Anyway, maybe that's still semantics. I'll take your point that an ice core is a photo of a thermometer; a fossil is a photo of a skeleton, but I don't dispute dinosaurs on that basis. Indeed most thermometers now take photos; recording snapshots of the temperature at that time. As all thermometers, like all temperature proxies, rely on thermometric variables, how do you ever know they are accurate without repeated recalibration? 
And of course it is possible to calibrate ice cores; you can measure layers from years within the recorded era, you can measure the isotopic mix in snow falling at different temperatures now, you can check your findings against other proxies. Might there be some other factor that means things happened differently in the past? Maybe. There might be some factor that means modern thermometers operate differently at night. But there's no sign of it, and the physical processes are well constrained. Ice core data tallies well with Milankovitch cycles - it seems surprising that would happen by chance.
BQSTART
The idea that lay people should stop thinking and prostrate themselves before the eminence of climate scientists is the antithesis of critical thinking.
BQEND
That's not the idea. Keep thinking, most definitely; question and challenge. But not just the scientists. There is middle ground where you know they might be wrong but you don't dismiss well established science with no evidence. That doesn't look very much like thinking to me.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1551291878000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they change proportionally to temperature', u'effect': u'that are useful'}], u'author_id': u'3919949', u'in_reply_to': u'126329186', u'id': u'126358902', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MoonlightTiger', u'text': u'We need Bernie Sanders.

An open Letter to President Macron from Hansen et al"July 1, 2017Dear President Macron,
We are writing as environmentalists, conservationists and climate scientists to congratulate you on your win in the presidential election, and to applaud your push for a carbon tax. Nobody has done more for advancing clean energy on the grid than France. In light of this knowledge, we are also writing to express our alarm at your decision to move France away from clean nuclear power.
Few nations have done more than France to demonstrate the humanitarian and environmental benefits of creating a high-energy, nuclear-powered, and electrified society. Not only was France host of United Nations climate talks, it also has some of the lowest per capita carbon emissions of any developed nation.
Any reduction in France’s nuclear generation will increase fossil fuel generation and pollution given the low capacity factors and intermittency of solar and wind. Germany is a case in point. Its emissions have been largely unchanged since 2009 and actually increased in both 2015 and 2016 due to nuclear plant closures. Despite having installed 4 percent more solar and 11 percent more wind capacity, Germany’s generation from the two sources decreased 3 percent and 2 percent respectively, since it wasn’t as sunny or windy in 2016 as in 2015.
And where France has some of the cheapest and cleanest electricity in Europe, Germany has some of the most expensive and dirtiest. Germany spent nearly 24 billion euros above market price in 2016 for its renewable energy production feed-in tariffs alone, but emissions have remained stagnant. Germany is set to miss its 2020 emission reduction goals by a wide margin. Despite its huge investment in renewables, only 46 percent of Germany’s electricity comes from clean energy sources as compared to 93 percent in France.
Solar and wind can play an important role in France. However, if France is to make investments in solar and wind similar to those of Germany, they should add to France’s share of clean energy, not inadvertently reduce it. Renewables can contribute to the further electrification of the transportation sector, which France has already done with its trains and should continue to do with personal vehicles.
Shifting from nuclear to fossil fuels and renewables would grievously harm the French economy in three ways: higher electricity prices for consumers and industry, an end to France’s lucrative electricity exports, and — perhaps most importantly — the destruction of France’s nuclear export sector. If the French nuclear fleet is forced to operate at lower capacity factors, it will cripple the French nuclear industry by adding costs and shrinking revenues. Eventually this will lead to poorer safety standards and less opportunities to fund research, development and efforts to export French nuclear technologies. Nations seeking to build new nuclear plants rightly want to know that the product France is selling is one that France itself values.
The French nuclear program has historically been the envy of the world. It demonstrated in the 1970s and 80s that the decarbonization of an industrialized country’s electricity sector is in fact possible. For France, the next necessary step to help combat climate change and improve air quality is to increase clean electricity from all non-fossil sources and massively reduce fossil fuels used in heating and the transportation sector. Nuclear power must play a central role in this.
Signed,James Hansen, Climate Science, Awareness, and Solutions Program, Columbia University, Earth Institute, Columbia University... and 47 others<a href="http://energyforhumanity.org/en/news-events/news/campaigns/open-letter-president-macron/">http://energyforhumanity.org/en/news-events/news/campaigns/open-letter-president-macron/
I agree with the scientists - you say you do too....', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1551257185000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'nuclear plant closures', u'effect': u'actually increased in both 2015 and 2016'}, {u'cause': u'this', u'effect': u'poorer safety standards and less opportunities to fund research'}], u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'126328362', u'id': u'126336105', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'curiouswes', u'text': u'BQSTART

Stanford experts reflect on the most destructive fire season in California history 
 

Decades of research show not only that the area burned in the West has been increasing, but also that global warming has been playing a role by increasing the dryness of vegetation on the landscape. The National Climate Assessment that was released by the U.S. government the day after Thanksgiving confirmed this evidence, highlighting that global warming has been responsible for around half of the historical increase in area burned.With regards to the conditions in California over the past few years, it is clear from multiple lines of evidence that California is now in a new climate, in which conditions are much more likely to be hot, leading to earlier melting of snowpack and exacerbating periods of low precipitation when they occur. The net effect is an extension of the fire season and greater potential for large, intense wildfires."

Experts Blame Multiple Causes for California Fires

Let your doctor know.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1551212046000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17975026', u'in_reply_to': u'126322567', u'id': u'126323513', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VettelCrashes', u'text': u'"Has it occurred to you that a thermometer is just a proxy for temperature change?"
If I asked you to define temperature, you probably couldn't. It's an extraordinary difficult thing to do, being that for an ideal gas it is actually an unmeasurable quantity (the mean kinetic energy of gas molecules, multiplied by two thirds of the Boltzmann constant).
The actual definition is the ratio of pressures of a fixed mass of gas, at constant volume (a quantity that can be measured) at Kelvin temperature T, to the pressure at the triple point of water multiplied by 273.16 (to give 100 divisions between freezing and boiling water), as measured by a constant volume gas thermometer.
The point is, temperature is the only physical property defined by the instrument that measures it. Hence a thermometer isn't a proxy for temperature, it actually is temperature. The property of the thermometer that changes is called a thermometric property.
A proxy may be thought of as a photograph of a thermometer. There's no way of knowing how it varies with temperature without generating a calibration curve, which would require a calibration curve.
The idea that lay people should stop thinking and prostrate themselves before the eminence of climate scientists is the antithesis of critical thinking.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1551225354000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100556257', u'in_reply_to': u'126318874', u'id': u'126329186', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ildfluer', u'text': u'Wow. description: Older politicians are too quick to write off younger climate activists. But where are their solutions to the climate crisis?
og_fields.og:description: Older politicians are too quick to write off younger climate activists. But where are their solutions to the climate crisis?
og_fields.og:title: Don't trust the adults in the room on climate change | Kate Aronoff
text:
There’s an inspiring new slogan gaining traction among venerated pundits and politicians of a certain age that claim steadfast commitment to the cause of stopping catastrophic climate change: “Get off my lawn.”
Most recently, California senator Dianne Feinstein, 85, scolded a group of middle-schoolers with the group Youth v Apocalypse, who had joined the Sunrise Movement to call on Feinstein to back a resolution in the Senate supporting a Green New Deal. In a now infamous exchange, Feinstein barked that “I know what I’m doing” and that she has “been doing this for 30 years”, so they better just bugger off and let the adults work. (To be fair, the video was edited to comply with Twitter’s content guidelines. In the full clip she also offers them an internship.)
When Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Senator Ed Markey introduced their resolution for the Green New Deal, House speaker Nancy Pelosi, 78, off-handedly called it the “green dream or whatever”, before backtracking later in the day and voicing support for the enthusiasm of the idea – just not the resolution itself. Months earlier, Congressman Frank Pallone, 67, battled Ocasio-Cortez’s resolution to create a select committee on the Green New Deal based on unfounded, territorial fears that it would undermine the authority of his prized energy and commerce committee.
Former Fed chairwoman Janet Yellen, 72, recently told the Financial Times the Green New Deal was simply too expensive to work, joining a record number of economists in backing a modest carbon tax as the more “feasible” and “sensible” option. New York Times columnist Gail Collins, 72, mused that Green New Deal campaigners would be better off sticking to “one really important climate-control thought”, perhaps – she spitballed – wind power: “If the country really threw itself into wind power, we could, er, breeze toward our goals on that alone.”
None of these figures deny climate change in the conventional sense of spouting junk science from rightwing thinktanks. They have all agreed publicly and even forcefully that climate change is a pressing issue, and that human activity is its cause. Several have been vocal advocates for climate action of one sort or another. But none have proposed a workable alternative to the economy-wide mobilization the Green New Deal sets out to accomplish, to rapidly electrify the American economy and reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2030. Details still need to be worked out on that plan, of course. But it remains the only idea on the table even remotely approaching the “wartime footing” climate scientists are increasingly insistent is necessary to avert catastrophe.
The kids, in other words, are right. They will also be the ones forced to live with the consequences of the choices politicians make in the next several years. That’s not an unfamiliar dynamic in climate politics. Residents of climate vulnerable nations who are already dealing with rising tides and temperatures have long been the ones pushing for the most ambitious action at the international level, chanting “1.5 to survive” through the halls of UN climate talks. Communities in the US forced to live with the health impacts of extraction – from Houston to the Bay Area – have for years sought an end to the drilling that’s threatening to cook us. As they have in the last few weeks, adults in the room – whether US negotiators at the UN or big beltway conservation organizations – have in each case offered sage counsel: be realistic!
Yet realism on climate means something different than it did even a decade or two ago, when a modest carbon tax and a smattering of tax credits might have gotten the job done. As the IPCC noted in its latest report, avoiding climate breakdown at this point will mean a “rapid, far-reaching and unprecedented changes in all aspects of society”, including massive investments in renewable energy and new technology and going to war with the world’s most powerful industry, fossil fuels.
Thankfully, Sunrise, Ocasio-Cortez and other Green New Deal advocates are updating our shared definition of what being realistic in a climate-changed 21st century looks like. The adults in the room would do well to listen.
Kate Aronoff is a freelance writer

description: The 16-year-old’s lone protest last summer has morphed into a powerful global movement challenging politicians to act
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: The 16-year-old’s lone protest last summer has morphed into a powerful global movement challenging politicians to act
og_fields.og:title: 'The beginning of great change': Greta Thunberg hails school climate strikes
text:
Greta Thunberg is hopeful the student climate strike on Friday can bring about positive change, as young people in more and more countries join the protest movement she started last summer as a lone campaigner outside the Swedish parliament.
The 16-year-old welcomed the huge mobilisation planned in the UK, which follows demonstrations by tens of thousands of school and university students in Australia, Belgium, Germany, the United States, Japan and more than a dozen other countries.
“I think it’s great that England is joining the school strike in a major way this week. There has been a number of real heroes on school strike, for instance in Scotland and Ireland, for some time now. Such as Holly Gillibrand and the ones in Cork with the epic sign saying ‘the emperor is naked’,” she told the Guardian.
With an even bigger global mobilisation planned for 15 March, she feels the momentum is now building.
“I think enough people have realised just how absurd the situation is. We are in the middle of the biggest crisis in human history and basically nothing is being done to prevent it. I think what we are seeing is the beginning of great changes and that is very hopeful,” she wrote.
Thunberg has risen rapidly in prominence and influence. In December, she spoke at the United Nations climate conference, berating world leaders for behaving like irresponsible children.
Last month, she had similarly harsh words for the global business elite at Davos. She said: “Some people, some companies, some decision-makers in particular, have known exactly what priceless values they have been sacrificing to continue making unimaginable amounts of money. And I think many of you here today belong to that group of people.”
The movement she started has morphed and grown around the world , and, at times, linked up with older groups, including Extinction Rebellion, 350.org and Greenpeace.
Next week she will take the train – having decided not to fly due to the high carbon emissions of aviation – to speak at an event alongside Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European commission, in Brussels, and then on to Paris to join the school strikes now expanding in France.
Veteran climate campaigners are astonished by what has been achieved in such a short time. “The movement that Greta launched is one of the most hopeful things in my 30 years of working on the climate question. It throws the generational challenge of global warming into its sharpest relief, and challenges adults to prove they are, actually, adults. So many thanks to all the young people who are stepping up,” said Bill McKibben, the founder of 350.org.
Around the world, so many student strikes are now taking place or planned that it is becoming hard to keep up. On Twitter, a supporter who posts under the name The Dormouse That Roared, has compiled a Google map that pins all the reported or announced locations, stretching from Abuja and Bugoloobi to Sacramento and Medellín. “This is not perfect by any means. It’s an emergency after all,” the online campaigner told the Guardian.
The most recent version shows thick clusters of activity, particularly in the UK and northern Europe. “#climatestrike. The house is on fire. Just wow!” wrote @dormouseroared, who is also collecting the different terms for “climate strike” in different languages.
In reply, people on Twitter have written, “I’ve been dreaming of this”, “Power to the children”, “beautiful” and simply “hope”.
Australia was one of the first countries to mobilise. Last November, organisers estimate 15,000 students went on strike. Last Friday, students lobbied outside the offices of the opposition party. On 1 March, they will target the federal treasurer’s office. Two weeks later, they will join the global strike.
They are demanding immediate political action to stop the Adani coalmine in Queensland, and a switch from fossil fuels to 100% renewable energy.
On Thursday, three student activists from Castlemaine in Australia – Callum Bridgefoot, 11; Harriet O’Shea Carre, 14 and Milou Albrechy,14 – spoke with the leader of the opposition in the federal parliament. “It’s a good sign that he is willing to meet,” they said. “The prime minister condemned the strike.”
The resources minister Matt Canavan was still more hostile, saying students would be better off learning about mining and science. “These are the type of things that excite young children and we should be great at it as a nation,” he told a local radio station. “The best thing you’ll learn about going to a protest is how to join the dole queue.”
In Belgium, there have been strikes by thousands of students for at least four consecutive weeks, with one now-famous placard – addressed to politicians and policymakers – reading: “I’ll do my homework when you do yours.”
More than 3,000 scientists have given their backing to the strikes. The Belgian government is clearly feeling the pressure. The environment minister was forced to resign after falsely claiming the country’s intelligence services held evidence that the striking children were being directed by unnamed powers. The allegation was quickly contradicted by intelligence chiefs.
Switzerland has seen some of the biggest actions. Local activists said 23,000 joined the strike on 18 January, followed by 65,000 on 2 February. They too are preparing for the global demonstration on 15 March. They want the government to immediately declare a climate state of emergency, implement policies to be zero-carbon by 2030 without geo-engineering, and if necessary move away from the current economic system.
Activists said they want to make clear that the problem is systematic rather than a matter of individual lifestyle choices. They have been criticised by right-wing politicians, but local governments have met student delegations to discuss short-term steps, such as a ban on any school trip that involves a flight. One regional authority has declared its support for the student movement. In an election year, state leaders have also expressed guarded support.
“For the moment, the government has reacted in a very paternalistic way. They say that it’s a good sign that the youth is demonstrating for its future but they don’t really do anything about it,” said Thomas Bruchez, a 20-year-old student at the University of Geneva. In two weeks, he said the organisers will prepare for the next nationwide strike, when they will consider how to involve workers and try to define more precise claims, such as free public transport financed by highly progressive taxes.
In Germany, activists told the Guardian there are mobilisations every week. Last Friday, there were 20,000 students striking in 50 cities. On 18 January, there were 30,000. And there will be another strike this Friday in at least 30 cities.
The global strike on 15 March is expected to be the biggest yet with mobilisations in 150 cities. “It is not acceptable that grown-ups are destroying the future right now,” said Jakob Blasel, a high-school student. “Our goal to stop coal power in Germany and fossil energy everywhere.” He said politicians have expressed admiration for their campaign, but this has not translated into action. “This is not acceptable. We won’t stop until they start acting.”
Until now 75% of the participants have been schoolchildren but increasing numbers of university students are joining. Luisa Neubauer, a 22-year-old, was among those invited to talk to senior cabinet officials. She told the German minister of economy that he was part of the problem because he was working for industry, rather than for people or the planet.
“What we need our politicians and our government to understand is that everything they do today comes at a price for future generations,” she said. “We are not doing this for fun, but because we don’t have a choice.”
But she too noted a new direction in the national discussion. “There is a debate now about climate and the environment, which is good. People for the first time in years are not talking about refugees but talking about the environment.”

description: Environmental and social problems could interact in global breakdown, report says
og_fields.og:description: Environmental and social problems could interact in global breakdown, report says
og_fields.og:title: Climate and economic risks 'threaten 2008-style systemic collapse'
text:
The gathering storm of human-caused threats to climate, nature and economy pose a danger of systemic collapse comparable to the 2008 financial crisis, according to a new report that calls for urgent and radical reform to protect political and social systems.
The study says the combination of global warming, soil infertility, pollinator loss, chemical leaching and ocean acidification is creating a “new domain of risk”, which is hugely underestimated by policymakers even though it may pose the greatest threat in human history.
“A new, highly complex and destabilised ‘domain of risk’ is emerging – which includes the risk of the collapse of key social and economic systems, at local and potentially even global levels,” warns the paper from the Institute for Public Policy Research. “This new risk domain affects virtually all areas of policy and politics, and it is doubtful that societies around the world are adequately prepared to manage this risk.”
Until recently, most studies of environmental risk tended to examine threats in isolation: climate scientists examined disruption to weather systems, biologists focused on ecosystem loss and economists calculated potential damages from intensifying storms and droughts. But a growing body of research is assessing how the interplay of these factors can create a cascade of tipping points in human society as well as the natural world.
The new paper – This is a Crisis: Facing up to the Age of Environmental Breakdown – is a meta-study of dozens of academic papers, government documents and NGO reports compiled by IPPR, a leftwing thinktank that is considered an influence on Labour policy.
The authors examine how the deterioration of natural infrastructure, such as a stable climate and fertile land, have a knock-on effect on health, wealth, inequality and migration, which in turn heightens the possibility of political tension and conflict.
The paper stresses the human impacts go beyond climate change and are occurring at speeds unprecedented in recorded history.
Evidence on the deterioration of natural systems is presented with a series of grim global statistics: topsoil is now being lost 10 to 40 times faster than it is being replenished by natural processes; the 20 warmest years since records began in 1850 have been in the past 22 years; vertebrate populations have fallen by an average of 60% since the 1970s, and insect numbers – vital for pollination – have declined even faster in some countries.
These processes amplify and interact with existing social and economic problems, potentially threatening systemic collapse similar to the 2008-9 financial crisis. Back then, a subprime mortgage crisis in the US exposed excessive risk-taking and triggered a global panic and the deepest recession since the 1930s. The IPPR study envisages a similar breakdown could occur if the US suffers relentlessly worsening damage from hurricane floods and forest fires, which would prompt a rush of insurance claims and threaten the viability of financial institutions.
“In the extreme, environmental breakdown could trigger catastrophic breakdown of human systems, driving a rapid process of ‘runaway collapse’ in which economic, social and political shocks cascade through the globally linked system – in much the same way as occurred in the wake of the global financial crisis of 2007-08,” the paper warns.
There are other potential cascades. The paper warns of the vulnerability of food systems that rely on just five animal and 12 plant species to provide 75% of the world’s nutrition. The lack of diversity weakens resilience to the growing risks of climate disruption, soil deterioration, pollution and pollinator loss. Previous research – cited by the IPPR – estimates a one-in-20 chance per decade of a simultaneous failure of maize production in the US and China, which provide 60% of the global supply.
Migration is also likely to increase as a result of longer droughts and more extreme heat, particularly in the Middle East and central and northern Africa.
Laurie Laybourn-Langton, the lead author of the report, said the climate crisis was likely to create 10 times more refugees from that region than the 12 million who left during the Arab spring.
“There would be repercussions in Europe. Rightwing groups use the fear of migration, as we saw during the EU referendum in Britain,” he said. “What is that going to look like when far more people are forced from homes due to environmental shocks? What does that mean for political cohesion.”
Several other recent interdisciplinary studies have highlighted the dangers of mutually reinforcing impacts. In December, the authors of a paper published in Science warned the risks were far greater than assumed because 45% of tipping points were interrelated and could amplify one another. Last August, scientists warns these domino effects could push the Earth into an almost uninhabitable “hothouse state”.
Studies of financial and social tipping points are scarcer, but concern is growing. Last month, the top three global risks identified by the World Economic Forum were extreme weather, climate policy failure and natural disasters. Water shortages, accelerating biodiversity loss and large-scale involuntary migration also ranked in the top 10.
“Of all risks, it is in relation to the environment that the world is most clearly sleepwalking into catastrophe,” its annual risk report warns. “The results of climate inaction are becoming increasingly clear. The accelerating pace of biodiversity loss is a particular concern.”
The IPPR report, which launches a wider 18-month project on this topic, urges policymakers to grapple with these risks as a priority, to accelerate the restoration of natural systems, and to push harder on the “green new deal” transition towards renewable energy. In particular, it says, “the younger generations will need help in finding the energy and a sense of control that often eludes them as they begin to realise the enormity of inheriting a rapidly destabilising world”.
Wider discussion is the first step, according to Laybourn-Langton, who said he was shocked by the paucity of public debate relative to the scale of the problems.
“People are not frank enough about this. If it is discussed at all, it is the sort of thing mentioned at the end of a conversation, that makes everyone look at the floor, but we don’t have time for that now,” he said. “It’s appearing more in media, but we are not doing enough.”
• This article was amended on 12 and 28 February 2019. After publication the IPPR issued corrections to their report, which originally said since 2005 the number of floods across the world has increased by 15 times, extreme temperature events by 20 times, and wildfires sevenfold. Those figures were based on a database that did not provide a complete record of natural disasters; those references have been removed from this article.

headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Party says Labour government would tackle climate change by starting economic revolution
og_fields.og:title: Labour to set out plans to decarbonise UK and fulfil green jobs pledge
text:
Labour is to set out how the UK can move swiftly to a decarbonised future to tackle the unfolding climate crisis and put “meat on the bones” of its promise to create hundreds of thousands of high-skilled, unionised green jobs.
Trade unionists and industry leaders will come together with academics, engineers and public institutions to build detailed regional plans setting out the challenges and opportunities ahead.
The proposal, due to be outlined on Wednesday by Rebecca Long-Bailey, the shadow business secretary, will involve a national call for evidence and a series of regional events to build “a detailed action plan” to maximise the benefits of moving to a zero-carbon future.
“A decade of austerity and decades of neoliberalism have left many in our country asking: what is Britain for?” Long-Bailey told the Guardian. “This has been brought into focus by the government’s handling of Brexit, which is at its core deeply pessimistic, with nothing to say about the future.”
She said a future Labour government would oversee an economic revolution to tackle the climate crisis, using the full power of the state to decarbonise the economy and create hundreds of thousands of green jobs in struggling towns and cities across the UK.
“We believe that together, we can transform the UK through a green jobs revolution, tackling the environmental crisis in a way that brings hope and prosperity back to parts of the UK that have been held back for too long.”
Last year a UN report said there were only 12 years left to avoid the worst impacts of climate breakdown. And this week a report said insects were facing extinction, threatening a “catastrophic collapse of nature’s ecosystems”, and another said climate change posed a “systemic risk” to the economy and society.
Labour’s pitch echoes the Green New Deal that is gaining ground in the US, backed by leftwing Democrats such as Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders.
Long-Bailey said Labour was determined to move beyond rhetoric about a green revolution and work out exactly how that could be achieved, and how it could translate to new well-paid, unionised jobs across the UK.
“We’re launching an unprecedented call for evidence about what this means for your town, your city, your region,” she said. “We want to bring unions, industry, universities, the public sector and others together to build this vision out into a practical reality.”
Labour says a key plank of its plan will be to ensure a “just transition” to high quality green jobs for those currently working in carbon-emitting industries. To do that it will have to persuade its trade union backers, who represent people in high-carbon industries, that there is a viable economic alternative.
The party hopes that once the evidence has been collected it will form the basis of a green paper to be published in autumn 2019 at party conference, with plans for how each region might move to a decarbonised future.
Long-Bailey told the Guardian last year that the climate crisis was “incredibly dangerous” and said the UK’s entire society and economy needed to be refocused to meet the looming challenge.
She said Tuesday’s announcement was a key step to realising that ambition. “This is not a blithe promise,” she said. “This is about the jobs at the end of your road. From the Clyde to the Humber to the Mersey. This about our future.”

description: The composer sailed to Antarctica to write a piece about climate change. She was overwhelmed by eerie silence, startling beauty – and the stench of penguin poo
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: The composer sailed to Antarctica to write a piece about climate change. She was overwhelmed by eerie silence, startling beauty – and the stench of penguin poo
og_fields.og:title: Composer Laura Bowler: my journey to the end of the world
text:
In recent years my work has become more and more socially and politically engaged – a colleague recently described it as “activist composition”. I’ve written a multimedia saxophone concerto challenging society’s ideas of femininity, I’ve written about anorexia, and I’ve tackled female boxing (which meant learning to box). My newest work is no different. I need to feel a sense of ownership and visceral experience of whatever it is that I’m writing about, so for a project focusing on climate change, it felt essential to find a way to get to the remotest and most untouched part of our planet – Antarctica.
For many of us living in urban environments, it’s difficult to understand the closeness that we can have to the environment. I wanted to travel to one of the most extreme parts of the world, a place almost as intangible and alien to the majority of the world’s population as climate change itself, and create a video and orchestral piece that gives people a sense of the absolute beauty and incredible nature of Antarctica, so that they will hopefully be more active in how they think about our planet.
My initial intention was to create a work that focused entirely on the Antarctic, but, as so often happens, my intentions were altered by the experience itself, and my composition became about the extraordinary voyage as much as the continent itself. In January 2018, I flew from London to Buenos Aires, then down to Ushuaia – fin del mundo – and from there I sailed across the Drake Passage down to the Antarctic peninsula. The crossing depends on the winds, but it’s roughly one week each way. We then spent two weeks sailing around the peninsula.
Sailing on the Bark Europa, a square-rigged tall ship, comes with the obligatory duties of being on watch. Essentially four hours on, eight hours off. (The main crew has a much more gruelling schedule of four hours on, four off.) Whatever the weather, this means getting up at midnight, 4am or 8am, clambering up the stairs to the deck and then being thrown into the elements. Climbing the rigging, hanging over the yards, steering on the helm, hauling ropes, watching out for icebergs was all part of the experience. All while wearing several layers of clothing that you have struggled into in the dark (not wanting to wake your fellow crew members), topped off with a safety layer in the form of a climbing harness, to ensure that the humungous waves crashing over the already severely heeling ship don’t throw you overboard.
Sailing across the Drake Passage was an exhilarating, exhausting and bitterly cold eight days. I’m an experienced sailor and was prepared for all of the above, but not for the sea sickness. I’ve never suffered from it before and was confident that I would be one of the lucky passengers who made it through without any tummy issues. I was wrong. I will never forget leaning over the side, while simultaneously trying to keep us on course at the helm in pitch-black darkness with sideways rain and the fear that the ship might capsize at any moment. This was one of the most exciting and awful moments of my life. How could it not become a part of the piece?
Gradually more and more icebergs started to appear and the ocean was getting calmer – signs that we were nearing the peninsula. The first time we stepped on land was at Deception Island. It was overwhelmingly beautiful.
But, before you step anywhere there, you have to place your boots in a bright pink antibacterial bath to ensure you don’t contaminate the habitat (and again when you come back on board the ship as well, so as not to contaminate subsequent sites). The shoreline was covered in thousands of penguins – mainly chipstrap penguins – accompanied by small groups of Weddell seals and a huddle of grunting young male elephant seals. I immediately started recording.
The initial excitement had temporarily clouded my other senses, but unfortunately my nose soon started working and I realised I was surrounded by the very potent, unpleasant smell of penguin poo. The stench followed us everywhere from that moment on until we returned to Tierra del Fuego.
Visiting Antarctica was an experience that will inform all of my future decisions about the way that I live my life
For me, there were three sound worlds. The first was the dry silence, particularly when we were drifting through the Lemaire Channel. The second was the the sound of the most active penguin colonies, the deafeningly loud constant barking alongside all their other sounds – exclamations, cries, squeaks and strange grunting. The third was the ice. I became obsessed with the variety of crackling, sizzling and fizzing qualities of the brash ice on the ocean’s surface.
All these elements became a significant part of the final work, through the audio recordings I made as well as through more expressionist interpretations. One challenge was the strange, eerie silence of Antarctica when we were anchored offshore surrounded by slow moving white giants of ice. I struggled for a long time with how to recreate this feeling through sound, finally landing on crystal singing bowls. Their pure, glass-like pitch with its seemingly never-ending resonance captured the sensation of the atmosphere during these moments of silence.
Unfortunately, there was also something else that intermittently decorated the landscape – human rubbish. Not left by tourists, but rubbish from around the world that had travelled on the ocean currents and washed up on these remote shores. Plastic microwave tubs, hairbrushes, straws, tin cans ... It was hugely distressing, but it also made me so angry to see the lack of care we have for the present and future of our planet.
Visiting Antarctica was an experience I will carry with me for ever, and one that will inform all my future decisions about the way that I live my life. But how could I process and communicate this in a piece of music? I didn’t want to shout at my audience and tell them what they should or should not do. Making a work that is in some way a political or social commentary is about probing and provoking questions, not necessarily about expressing demands or solutions.
I decided to give human form to things. In a variety of costumes I embody the fossil fuel frenzy, a futuristic weather woman, or, with a large Earth on my head and a gas mask, the barely surviving planet itself. The final third of the work uses satire, science and melting ice (projected on to a large screen from an on-stage blue box containing large melting ice cubes) in an attempt to communicate the severity of our environmental crisis. It’s as intense, guilty and declamatory as the earlier depiction of Antarctica is serene, spacious and innocent.
• Laura Bowler’s Antarctica (a co-commission between Manchester Camerata and BBC Radio 3) will be broadcast on Radio 3’s Hear and Now on 2 March.

The common leave-taking formula, Tchüß or Tchüßi, is often explained as a derivative from á Dieu or adieu. This I accepted until I heard a German-Dutch speaker's mother use a very similar sounding expression: ' schütze dich', a reduction of the formula God protect you, or "(mag) Gott schutze dich/Sie" in English "may God protect you". This is a Platt-Deutch variant of the go-with-god  leave-taking found in many European languages.
"In Hamburg sagt man Tschüß/ das heißt auf Wiedersehen" as the song goeth.

If you find it difficult, try a bit harder.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550330707000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16462578', u'in_reply_to': u'125873043', u'id': u'125933832', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'C9gfKyy423', u'text': u'"Won't the pictures of abroad be imperialist and orientalist etc, and thus best forgotten?"
Uhmmm, no, no and no.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550330437000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16462578', u'in_reply_to': u'125855579', u'id': u'125933754', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'As this discussion is still open, please allow me to mention the Conan Doyle book again. I found it and dug it out and it is an interesting account of his 1880 whaling voyage. The edition is in facsimile and has his drawings and watercolours reproduced. He was on the summer hunt to the northwest of Spitzbergen (Svalbard) and the ice he drew from that season was either loose ice or "fast ice" of about 6-8 feet in height. At some later point he gave lectures about his views on the Arctic and sided with those who believed there was an "open polar sea" in the North rather than a polar ice cap. He also claimed in 1892 that above the 82° there was a "single mighty wall" extending across the horizon of old ice. 
Conan Doyle's log book was brought out as "Dangerous Work"[U of Chicago 2012] and is an interesting personal account of his Arctic voyage. 
Tshüss, Chris Brown', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550323056000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'125930498', u'id': u'125931923', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bellas1', u'text': u'Those flat earthers are funny but sadly they are often anti-vaccine too. Mind you, I remember one bored afternoon searching for something and landing on an alien conspiracy site. As I read through the site, I started to think 'what if it's true?" That was the point I gave myself a talking to and moved on. However, it highlighted o me just how easy it is to be drawn into these things. 
I agree about the watercolours, a great idea and a great resource.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550318398000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11000540', u'in_reply_to': u'125928750', u'id': u'125930498', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'I too had a look in the internet to see what sort of graphics I could find of either old photos or illustrative drawings of the "ice barrier" and didn't find much of interest. I did run into a bizarre flat earth society website that was somehow trying to claim that the pizza shaped world was surrounded by an ice edge and that all scientific bodies were involved in a conspiracy to mislead the world and convince us that the world was a ball. As if the world hadn't been circumnavigated hundreds of years ago. I'd heard of such a weird belief but thought it was a hoax.
Anyway, this article interested me as I didn't know there was any systematic attempt to catalogue the drawings and watercolours done by travelers and natural historians. Both efforts are laudable.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550313435000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'125915522', u'id': u'125928750', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Why are you dragging Jesus into this? You are obviously exasperated and exasperating.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550251054000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'125897514', u'id': u'125915713', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bellas1', u'text': u'I'm sure we have a 'Boy's Own' annual in the house somewhere and the cover is similar.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550250534000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11000540', u'in_reply_to': u'125914911', u'id': u'125915522', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Good luck. The pictures I had in mind were the illustrations to a book on the whaling hunt which Conan Doyle went on as a ship's doctor. Another example are rather fanciful drawings of the ice encountered by Capt Cook on his explorations of the Bering Sea. These were made for a popular version of a Jules Verne book on explorers.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550249143000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'125908920', u'id': u'125914911', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bellas1', u'text': u'You will distinguish because you have the knowledge. However, Watercolour World is open to the general public hence my caution.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550239198000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'you have the knowledge', u'effect': u'you will distinguish'}], u'author_id': u'11000540', u'in_reply_to': u'125907015', u'id': u'125909057', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bellas1', u'text': u'That's interesting. I've seen paintings of ice walls such as you refer to and not stopped to wonder about their authenticity. I can't of course argue that the ice shelves aren't in retreat but have to consider artistic licence etc. Let's face it, most artists were painting what sold and nature, the rawer the better, did have its fashion. Off to look and see if I can find the earliest photographs of ice walls online now :)', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550238986000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11000540', u'in_reply_to': u'125905289', u'id': u'125908920', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidBates', u'text': u'It may have been a bit of a leap, but I think I'd distinguish between paintings done for aesthetic purposes which may well have a degree of artistic license about them v's those painted as a record of what was there - the painting of Lahore being a good example. My library has some geographical handbooks from the early 20th Century covering different parts of the world with a range of illustrations which were designed specifically to show what key points would look like from certain angles. Inside the front is the legend that they are top secret and should be returned to...I think it was the Royal Navy. I suspect that the painting of Lahore falls into a similar category, ie, a working document rather than a decorative work of art. With reference to artistic license - I was once on a painting holiday when somebody commented that what we were looking at would make a beautiful painting if only certain trees weren't in the way. The art teacher responded "Then don't paint the trees in - that's what makes this art and not photography. You don't think all those landscape paintings included everything that was there do you?"', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550236212000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2645592', u'in_reply_to': u'125865807', u'id': u'125907015', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Of course making claims about the historical accuracy of pictures can be misleading even in photographs. One place where this comes into question is depictions of the ice "barrier" around the Arctic and Antarctic. Such barriers are often depicted in paintings as steep walls.
Whether this pack ice was really so thick as recently as 1900 is open to debate. Accounts in sea logs also refer to whaling ships sheltering in the lee of these walls of ice. What we know for sure is that no such massive walls of ice currently exist in the Northern hemisphere and only the glacial ice shelves around Antarctica still show anything comparable to what was described as a "barrier" by earlier polar explorers.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550233778000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'125865807', u'id': u'125905289', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'This seems to be a new classification of a cloud type and has been documented mostly in the Midwest of the USA. I'm not familiar with this name Asperitas so I had to look it up to get an idea of what you are talking about. Wiki discusses possible mechanisms in cloud formation that lead to the formation of this kind of undulating cloud bank. It seems to be associated with storm build up and dissipation. It may be linked to tornadoes. At the end of the Wiki entry there was this curious comment:
"series of sightings of the cloud, which were interpreted as being associated with the propagation of gravity waves through a pre-existing cloud layer."
Giving something a name helps people recognize it but you may be right that it is a seldom occurrence that has become more frequent, just as tornadoes are becoming much more widespread than in my youth.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550233033000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'the formation of this kind of undulating cloud bank'}], u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'125887578', u'id': u'125904695', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CameronsTopHat', u'text': u'What do the poor have to do with anything? Population is the problem and counties that set their own (non) regulation otherwise there is literally no point in half the world sifling themselves whilst the other half burp out emissions at an exponentially increasing rate. If the plan is to have no effect on global emissions that's fine, but I thought the idea was to reduce them? Not to just self flagellate.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550224514000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11555262', u'in_reply_to': u'125866792', u'id': u'125897699', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CameronsTopHat', u'text': u'Yeah, yeah punish the West, glory to communism. Jesus.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550224284000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11555262', u'in_reply_to': u'125862036', u'id': u'125897514', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CameronsTopHat', u'text': u'These figures... Firstly how would they get accurate data for a country like China? China has the highest industrial output of any nation and a population four times that of the US. Even using those figures you've proved my point that China produces nearly twice the carbon dioxide the US does. Americans consume huge volumes of goods produced in countries like China. Does that consumption fall on the American or the Chinese side of these figures, I would expect the former which would scew the data further...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550224244000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11555262', u'in_reply_to': u'125860161', u'id': u'125897483', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'vank', u'text': u'Thank you. Much appreciated.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550222247000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3953236', u'in_reply_to': u'125854213', u'id': u'125895882', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ikenuma', u'text': u'I went to an exhibition some years ago at the Dulwich Picture Gallery; The Golden Age of British Watercolour if I recall and it featured works by John Sell Cotman and his contemporaries.
Amongst them were papers of small studies for portraits; old Arabs with handsome faces, camel herders, merchants and sheiks painted in the 1700s. They were beautifully painted and it struck me these were the very same faces I had seen earlier that year in the Atlas Mountains of Morocco and in Egypt. What a wonderful record.
It not only got me to take up watercolour painting from a position of ‘nil talent’ in place of photography but has lead to enjoyable travels seeking out watercolour paintings to gaze upon.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550213887000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'enjoyable travels seeking out watercolour paintings to gaze upon'}], u'author_id': u'3083688', u'id': u'125892316', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TSmithNoCrackers', u'text': u'My wife has been researching how, in the late 1800s, there were a great number of well-educated Brits, Americans, French, Russians, etc. going into the Far East. Many of them (including many women) were quite talented with watercolor, and yes, most of their art is kept in archives of various kinds, which means that few people have ever had the chance to see them. But as this article points out, these artists were often seeing things that no longer can be seen today. Some may deride this stuff as "imperialistic" or "orientalist," but in many cases it's all we have. Many of these "amateurs" had received extensive artistic training but went into other occupations. Many of them also had contact with artists in the countries they visited--how much cultural exchange was going on, not just between the elite artists, but among ordinary people who just liked a good picture? This is a huge but underexplored field, so a project like "Watercolour World" discussed in the article should help bring more of this art to light.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550207707000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16446064', u'id': u'125891267', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'I love the Marianne North gallery at Kew. Used to visit often when I lived near there. What a woman she was!!!', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550187964000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'id': u'125887934', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'More of these, please', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550187543000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'id': u'125887807', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Guy_Denning', u'text': u'I think the idea of using this resource for pre-photographic evidence of climactic states is potentially very useful. I made a comment a few years back on the Guardian about asperitas cloud formations and how I could never remember seeing them in my childhood despite painting landscapes from observation as a child (don't take the piss). And I knew that if I had witnessed them I would've painted them. Admittedly I don't see them every day, and I have moved from Somerset to Brittany, but they're not an unknown occurrence here. I suggested that if they were about in the times of Turner (for example) he would've no doubt painted them if only for the dramatic content of a painting. Interestingly someone replied who I presume was of a scientific bent and said that relatively little research had been focused on clouds but that this was starting to change. I know a negative is difficult to prove but if there are no depictions of cloud formations like asperitas in visual art history then that could suggest more evidence of another change in our atmosphere.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550186768000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13742367', u'id': u'125887578', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'lsrnyc', u'text': u'What an great idea and an astonishing project. that's the beauty of computing and the WWW', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550158217000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'345061', u'in_reply_to': u'125861615', u'id': u'125872991', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bellas1', u'text': u'Italian painters were using the camera obscura in the early 18th C, not a lot of photos about from then.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550158154000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11000540', u'in_reply_to': u'125867457', u'id': u'125872945', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'peterdew', u'text': u'he is infamous but was a reasonable painter as well', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550158116000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'345061', u'in_reply_to': u'125861523', u'id': u'125872917', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'peterdew', u'text': u'perhaps surprisingly, there are a still a lot of people around who can do that', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550158038000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'345061', u'in_reply_to': u'125866420', u'id': u'125872849', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'peterdew', u'text': u'Lets hope that it gives TG's Jonathan Jones a better appreciation of the true value of art.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550157893000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'345061', u'id': u'125872725', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Groan2', u'text': u'Missing from this debate is the role of the camera obscura and the aesthetic movement towards more explicitly matter-of-fact depictions in landscape and topographical drawing and painting. In the late 19th century it was note uncommon for a topographical draftsman/artist to state when and where a particular sketch was drawn or, as was the term then, "taken". To make this more explicit, and to use the factual to express the metaphorical - the state of ruined buildings portraying the decline of Classical civilisation, the evidence of the wear of the centuries in the daily dying of the light etc., - many sketches were drawn with close attention to the recording of shadows etc as much as details of the state of the masonry etc.Making the weather fit - well, look at the positive correlation between sunny weather and volume of photographs..', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550151095000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15776725', u'in_reply_to': u'125866026', u'id': u'125867457', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID3732233', u'text': u'Superb and far reaching idea. Not just watercolors, but pencil drawings and architectural plans etc hidden away; a wealth of information readily at hand, especially if collated properly.My own interest in art is the direct result of seeing watercolors, etchings and pencil drawings from the late 18th and 19th century hanging on our walls as a child. We had little money, but we still had those artifacts. As time has passed, much of that; wonderfully done landscapes and city views, have been relegated to hallway closets as relatives disperse, die or do not pass on the history to the next generation.I recall several non romanticized pastoral scenes with specific location detail gone forever. As a recent article in The Guardian pointed out, we have history from the point of view of the One Percenters and practically no history of a people. Hopefully this effort will change that and bring us into some historical focus.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550145806000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10031037', u'id': u'125862948', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dave6723', u'text': u'Since it's cumulative emissions that matter, and most of those are down to the West, the West should bear the brunt of the burden. And don't forget who the most famous watercolour painter of the past century was...', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550136907000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10365866', u'id': u'125855579', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NigelN', u'text': u'Whilst recognising the artistic importance of these paintings, viewers need to be aware of William Gilpin and his picturesque movement before using any individual painting as evidence of anything.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550136653000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2804805', u'id': u'125855351', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidB2', u'text': u'Looking at watercolours on the website of scenes I know, I have to say that to make this collection truly useful, it will need a massive public input in terms of correction and clarification. In addition to views which are simply mis-labelled / incorrectly mapped, there are inevitably many which distort to absurdity the scenes they claim to represent.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550136376000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3321879', u'id': u'125855129', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Moosetasticols', u'text': u'This is a fantastic project.
"Between the invention of the spool camera around 1900 (which instantly superseded the pocket watercolour box as documentary tool of choice) and the advent of mass commercial colour photography in the 1950s, we lost, in terms of such deliberate documentary records, half a century of colour."
If I see a stunning view that I want to remember, even in the age of the smartphone, I sit down and draw it. Not only do you get to really appreciate the moment, but the image and sensation is etched into your memory in a way no photo seems to achieve.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550135153000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16795454', u'id': u'125854481', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Holt', u'text': u'A Tibetan Weaver, 1895, by William Simpson', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550134529000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12893534', u'in_reply_to': u'125854143', u'id': u'125854213', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'vank', u'text': u'What is the title and the name of the painter of the first picture? The two women sitting and a church in the background? I can not see it but would appreciate if someone writes it.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550134372000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3953236', u'id': u'125854143', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Here's an important paper published last month from PNAS showing a similar trend on the biggest piece of ice on the planet, titled: Four decades of Antarctic Ice Sheet mass balance from 1979–2017
BQSTART
We use updated drainage inventory, ice thickness, and ice velocity data to calculate the grounding line ice discharge of 176 basins draining the Antarctic Ice Sheet from 1979 to 2017. 
We compare the results with a surface mass balance model to deduce the ice sheet mass balance. The total mass loss increased from 40 ± 9 Gt/y in 1979–1990 to 50 ± 14 Gt/y in 1989–2000, 166 ± 18 Gt/y in 1999–2009, and 252 ± 26 Gt/y in 2009–2017.
In 2009–2017, the mass loss was dominated by the Amundsen/Bellingshausen Sea sectors, in West Antarctica (159 ± 8 Gt/y), Wilkes Land, in East Antarctica (51 ± 13 Gt/y), and West and Northeast Peninsula (42 ± 5 Gt/y). 
The contribution to sea-level rise from Antarctica averaged 3.6 ± 0.5 mm per decade with a cumulative 14.0 ± 2.0 mm since 1979, including 6.9 ± 0.6 mm from West Antarctica, 4.4 ± 0.9 mm from East Antarctica, and 2.5 ± 0.4 mm from the Peninsula (i.e., East Antarctica is a major participant in the mass loss). 
During the entire period, the mass loss concentrated in areas closest to warm, salty, subsurface, circumpolar deep water (CDW), that is, consistent with enhanced polar westerlies pushing CDW toward Antarctica to melt its floating ice shelves, destabilize the glaciers, and raise sea level.
BQEND
https://www.pnas.org/content/116/4/1095', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550134331000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'125853985', u'id': u'125854123', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EGriff', u'text': u'That's the important information: that retreat was greater in 2000-2010 than in a hundred years before.

Have a photograph taken in 1971 . Its retreat is phenomenal and rather sad. Markings on the rocks show just how far the ice has retreated.
It's too late to tackle climate change . Should have been started years ago but that requires cooperation and agreement. 
Brexit is a perfect analogy. Put your head in the sand and pretend it's just not happening.', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550133384000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10233657', u'id': u'125853728', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'In the last part of the video Balog notes that Jakobshavn Glacier retreated more between 2000-2010 than it did between 1900-2000.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550132934000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'125852853', u'id': u'125853531', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Fascinating article! From it: "Hohler cites the recently reported projected loss of a third of the Himalayan ice-fields. The only visual record we have of what those glaciers looked like 150 years ago – relative to today – is in watercolours."
A more recent artist, the photographer James Balog, made the documentary Chasing Ice where he placed dozens of time lapse cameras across the North to document the retreat of glaciers.
Here's a 5 minute clip that the film crew from that documentary captured (largest calving event ever filmed) of a piece of ice the size of lower Manhattan calving off of Jakobshavn Glacier in Greenland.

description: A new website is digitising millions of watercolours – to make instantly available a wealth of vital historic imagery that could assist everything from climate research to school teachers
headline: O
og_fields.og:description: A new website is digitising millions of watercolours – to make instantly available a wealth of vital historic imagery that could assist everything from climate research to school teachers
og_fields.og:title: Our lost world in watercolours – the paintings that documented Earth
text:
Hot in the footsteps of Art UK’s ambitious attempt to document every publicly owned artwork in Britain on a single website, a new online project has launched to repeat the project for the world’s watercolours – in particular those that, accidentally or on purpose, documented that world.
Watercolour World is the brainchild of former diplomat Fred Hohler, whose first large-scale digitisation endeavour, the Public Catalogue Foundation, laid the groundwork for Art UK. The idea came to Hohler when he embarked on a tour of Britain’s public collections and realised quite how much there was to do on watercolour alone: Norwich Castle Museum held about 4,500 paintings by a single artist; the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew, meanwhile, had somewhere between 200,000-300,000 watercolours in its drawers. 
The value – and excitement – of the Watercolour World project, is that it views these historic paintings as documents, not aesthetic objects: visual records of the world at large, in colour, spanning a full 150 years before photography took over as our primary documentary medium. Between the invention of the spool camera around 1900 (which instantly superseded the pocket watercolour box as documentary tool of choice) and the advent of mass commercial colour photography in the 1950s, we lost, in a sense, half a century of colour.
The website, which has launched with about 80,000 works, focuses on pre-1900 documentary paintings: archival information gathering often duly kept in binders and boxes ever since. Some of the artists on the site were professional painters. Others were military draughtsmen, official expedition watercolourists, botanists, surveyors, as well as the untold numbers of amateurs – which Hohler suspects will turn out to have mostly been women, unpaid for their time and skill – who picked up a paintbrush to record the world around them.
The website has started with already digitised pieces from public collections: the Rijksmuseum, Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Musée des Beaux-Arts d’Orléans, to name some. Hohler is most excited, though, about what’s hiding in private archives, if only because most owners don’t even realise what they’ve got. “They all say the same thing,” he says: “‘Oh, we don’t have much.’” But often they do – hidden away in an attic or empty trunks in the living room.
This unintentional neglect is why many of the works are in sterling condition: light and handling threaten both pigment and paper; forgetting about artworks doesn’t. While official draughtsmen used the best archival paper, amateurs worked on whatever they could find. Which lends an added incentive to the digitisation Hohler’s team is undertaking: many of these paintings have a shelf life, yet what they depict is potentially of vital importance.
Hohler goes so far as to say that once the collection reaches the critical mass of 1m images, it will be an “absolutely indispensable tool to help us understand today”. From coastal erosion and ice-cap melt to loss of fauna and flora, not to mention direct human destruction (of Palmyra in Syria, say, by Islamic State, or the Seti tomb in Luxor, by tourists) these watercolours serve as an invaluable reference.
Hohler cites the recently reported projected loss of a third of the Himalayan ice-fields. Most of the visual records we have of what those glaciers looked like 150 years ago is in watercolours. Among the images on the website is the first known, yet accidental, picture of Mount Everest, from the 1840s: it’s not even labelled Everest. A lot of the value in these images is similarly accidental. Often it’s the context – replete with treelines, snowlines or waterlines – the artist painted around, for example, the flower they’d set out to record.
Anyone with a phone can send in picture of a historical watercolour they might have lying about, to see if it’s worth cataloguing
As Hohler puts it: “We have in this country all these images about, not this country, but the rest of the world – and they’re stuffed in drawers.” Beyond the UK, he has no idea quite how many images there are, worldwide, to be catalogued, but estimates it to be in the millions. The task is clearly not something his team will ever accomplish alone: the project is as much a call to arms as a public service. Anyone with a phone can send in a picture of a historical watercolour they might have lying about, to see if it’s worth cataloguing. And the more people do so, the more complete a picture of the bygone world this collection will provide.
These watercolours, for the most part, even come with built-in metadata. The website retains the original caption information (even when it’s mistaken) as supplied by the collections the images come from. The team then tags them with appropriate search terms to help people find interesting stuff.
And interesting stuff there is: from the French revolutionary knife grinder with his two canine assistants (search for “dogs”) to the students and their camel at a Marylebone boarding school (there are 366 images tagged with “camel”; search instead for “boarding school”). Teachers will have a field day. And, Hohler’s team suspects, so will any punter as curious about their own neck of the woods as they are about far-flung lands.
