I’m just saying you are terribly oversimplifying the issue.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550000657000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'losses can occur to any investor', u'effect': u'sometimes happens is done by any investor'}], u'author_id': u'15456519', u'in_reply_to': u'125756040', u'id': u'125797079', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fraser48', u'text': u'The real problem appears to be facing up to and doing something about the all too obvious fact that the 1% are using their obscene levels of wealth, power and influence to frustrate any meaningful action .They both fear that it will impede their attempts to further increase their wealth, power and influence and also believe that that same wealth power and influence will insulate them from the future armageddon their behaviour will cause.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549967002000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'their behaviour', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'13952083', u'id': u'125771772', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bobble4293', u'text': u'BQSTART
Ban all forms of purchasing from China. And the planet will breathe again
BQEND
Historically, China tried to ban imports of opium, brought to them by the East India Company, but we Brits didn't like that...https://www.nam.ac.uk/explore/opium-war-1839-1842
If you think the Chinese have forgotten and forgiven, think again. In any case, much of what they produce, from computers to hand and machine tools, is produced at the request of US corporations. Taking hand tools as an example, I was in Homebase last year, and saw a box of spanners labelled "Crescent", a long established US manufacturer, in a cardboard sleeve reminiscent of the packaging style of toys. My first adjustable spanner was a Crescent tool, from Jamestown, New York state. These Crescent tools were Chinese made, at the behest of the US "Apex Tools Group", and a little investigation showed that many of the traditionally American tool manufacturers absorbed into the Apex group have been closed down and their production offshored to China, to increase margins.The knock-on effect is that while, when I was a youth, British and US tools were superior in so many ways to Asian imports (mainly Japanese and Indian), people like Apex have provided the Chinese with the product name, production methods, the metallurgy and designs, to make high quality goods, plus a market into which American brand names can be sold... This is not going to change any time soon. The only likely change is that we'll see more, and better high quality Chinese clones of US tools, which will sell, once the first few buyers, without the traditional prejudice towards known makes, try them and find them to be good value.We're screwed, by a combination of our unwillingness to pay domestic industry's prices, and the domestic industry's proprietors' pursuit of profit.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549966679000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4100535', u'in_reply_to': u'125761912', u'id': u'125771527', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'It's been increasingly obvious on at least an anecdotal basis for a long time, and other research studies have been pointing this way for some time.
Anecdotally, not too many years ago, car windscreens and headlamps were normally heavily dotted with dead insects after a typical drive - but this never seems to happen now. I certainly remember that happening.
Here's a research paper published in 2017:
"More than 75 percent decline over 27 years in total flying insect biomass in protected areas" - Hallmann et al, 2017
A quote from the abstract:
BQSTART
Our analysis estimates a seasonal decline of 76%, and mid-summer decline of 82% in flying insect biomass over the 27 years of study. 
We show that this decline is apparent regardless of habitat type, while changes in weather, land use, and habitat characteristics cannot explain this overall decline.
BQEND
I think this project was possibly the first systematic study of the issue.
I hope this helps answer your point.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549986465000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'125776833', u'id': u'125788893', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'oneness', u'text': u'Dear Guardian,Please make up your mind on which incompatible issue you support. Either the above or your counter editorial of this edition "The Guardian view on the UK economy: before Brexit, rescue it from austerity". You can't have remedies to counteract ecological breakdown and economic growth. I suggest the former complemented by a reduction in consumerism (entailing a reduction of advertising for unnecessary stuff), wealth taxation and redistribution and full participatory democracy - and above all, justice.YoursOneness', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549986300000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1017813', u'id': u'125788772', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CLeighton', u'text': u'Another huge problem for us to worry about but with no useful suggestionson how to address it. Sure, we have the UN Biodiversity Protocol where allcountries (except the US) agreed that something 'Should' be done. This is muchthe same as the UN Climate Change Agreement of 1992 (UNFCCC) when allcountries (including the US) agreed that 'urgent' action 'Should' be taken toprevent dangerous climate change. That is as far as UN agreements go.When countries have to commit to actually do anything, the agreements collapse.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550000023000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101346019', u'id': u'125796900', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kent31', u'text': u'“Since most of the globalisation took place during the last couple of decades, after the concept of limits to growth was known, they were acting irresponsible. They took insane risks every sensible rational person would baulk at, and we now have to live with the consequences.”
Regarding the banking crisis, much of that was due to liberal congressional initiatives to loosen home ownership lending standards. Yes, the banks rolled with it, but it was initiated to enable more home ownership for more people because rules were “unfair”. That effort to be fair meant people got loans for which they weren’t really qualified.

description: Editorial: Global warming and industrialised farming are damaging vital ecosystems
og_fields.og:description: Editorial: Global warming and industrialised farming are damaging vital ecosystems
og_fields.og:title: The Guardian view on the mass death of insects: this threatens us all | Editorial
text:
One of the classic science-fiction treatments of the end of civilisation was The Death of Grass, by John Christopher, in which a mysterious sickness struck down all the grasses on which most of the world’s agriculture is based, from rice to wheat. In the end, politics among the survivors of plague, war and famine was reduced to a bitter fratricidal struggle over a defensible potato patch. Like most of the so-called “cosy catastrophe” novels, this could be criticised for optimism. Grim though a future of famine and the war of all against all might seem, the consequences were largely confined to humans.
The threatened extinction of insect populations around the world raises the prospect of a much more general catastrophe, which would implicate plants, birds, fish, small mammals, and everything else that depends on insects. That’s just the start. Other species, and we ourselves, depend on the animals and plants that need insects. When they go, we go. This is not just a greater catastrophe. It’s a much more plausible one. The most recent study concluded that insect biomass is decreasing around the world at a rate of 2.5% a year. At that rate, half the insects in the world will be gone in 50 years’ time, and all of them in a century – although no one will be keeping track of centuries then.
The chief driver of this catastrophe is unchecked human greed. For all our individual and even collective cleverness, we behave as a species with as little foresight as a colony of nematode worms that will consume everything it can reach until all is gone and it dies off naturally. The challenge of behaving more intelligently than creatures that have no brain at all will not be easy. But unlike the nematodes, we know what to do. The UN convention on biodiversity was signed in 1992, alongside the convention on climate change. Giving it the strength to curb our appetites is now urgent. Biodiversity is not an optional extra. It is the web that holds all life, including human life.
The two main expressions of greed that hasten this apocalypse are global warming and industrial agriculture. It appears that most of the damage is being done in the developed world by farming practices. The use of giant fields, devoid of shelter for insects of any sort at all, whether they are harmful to human interests or not, and where the plants are drenched in long-lasting pesticides, has been fatal for uncounted billions of insects. The effects of this kind of farming reach beyond the fields immediately affected, too. There has been a huge loss of aquatic insect species from the rivers into which the products of industrial agriculture are flushed by rain. Even in German nature reserves, which are by definition protected from the use of pesticides, there have been steep falls in insect populations because so many of the most widely used ones are persistent and prevent breeding. In the tropics, the steady rise of global temperatures is already devastating whole ecosystems, starting at the bottom with the insects. Last year we learned of the disappearance of almost all the ground-dwelling insects from a rainforest in Puerto Rico, and three-quarters of the species of the canopy. 
Some governments have done some necessary things. The EU has banned neonicotinoid pesticides. But the necessary change also relies on individual action. As individuals we must consume less in every way, which helps with climate change. We must also change our food habits. To eat less meat and more organic is not just piety. A little self-restraint in this generation will make all the difference to our grandchildren.

description: Actor attacked Trump and other leaders at World Government Summit for denying science to justify not facing the ‘moral crisis’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Actor attacked Trump and other leaders at World Government Summit for denying science to justify not facing the ‘moral crisis’
og_fields.og:title: Harrison Ford: leaders who deny climate change are 'on the wrong side of history'
text:
Harrison Ford has launched a scorching attack on Donald Trump and other world leaders, for denying science in order to justify doing nothing to face the “moral crisis” of climate change.
The actor best known for fighting off Imperial stormtroopers as Han Solo and writhing in snake pits as Indiana Jones has now taken on the combined might of climate change deniers, with Trump a top target. Though Ford did not mention the US president by name, the subject of his speech at the final day of the World Government Summit in Dubai was beyond doubt.
“Around the world,” he said, “elements of leadership including in my own country to preserve their state and the status quo, deny or denigrate science. They are on the wrong side of history.”
Ford, at 76 four years Trump’s senior, has long been a campaigner for global environmental protection. He prefaced his speech at the summit with a short film, narrated in his trademark lion’s growl, featuring the character of Nature speaking about the future.
“If I’m not kept healthy, humans won’t survive, simple as that,” Nature says. “I could give a damn with or without humans, I’m the ocean. I covered this entire planet once, and I can always cover it again.”
Climate change denial and skepticism about established scientific truth have long been embraced by Trump. He has been propagating conspiracy theories about global warming since at least 2012, when he claimed it was a ruse by China to gain an unfair manufacturing advantage over the US.
In June 2017 Trump withdrew the US from the Paris agreement to limit global pollution levels and control temperature rise. Last November he responded to a dire US climate assessment by 13 government agencies and top scientists with the blunt words: “I don’t believe it.”
Only on Sunday, Trump issued yet another denigrating tweet in which he sought to mock the Democratic senator from Minnesota Amy Klobuchar, who had just launched a 2020 presidential bid, but ended up mocking climate science. He noted that Klobuchar had addressed global warming in her speech as snow fell around her.
“Bad timing,” Trump said.
In an interview with CNN before his Dubai appearance, Ford criticized directly the Trump administration for being “bent on dismantling all of the gains we’ve made in the protection of the environment”.
He lamented the “isolationism, nationalism that’s creeping into governments all across the developed world. The problems require attention on nature’s scale not on the scale of the next election.”
In his address to the summit, Ford called climate change “the greatest moral crisis of our time. We need nature now more than ever because nature doesn’t need people, people need nature.”

As you have to have them already running at 50% whether you need that electricity or not, they are not as flexible as hydroelectricity or gas turbines. "what is your line connection cost today?"

Because when a grid operator needs a 100MW reduction in the next 10 minutes, they need 100MW, as measured in watts. Either a plant can slew that 100MW, or it can't. 
More generally, the watt is the SI unit of power.A rate of change of power has the units Ws⁻¹. Minutes are also an acceptable and widely used unit of time. We should just treat this as the planetary emergency it is.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550125793000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'125850878', u'id': u'125851435', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'If you are a rancher who has lost their cattle to drought, or a homeowner who has lost their home to wildfire or flood, or an island nation going under the waves, then dangerous climate change has already arrived.
Just a two hour drive from me last summer the Camp Fire incinerated the town of Paradise, CA. It could have been my town and who knows if my town isn't next?
When will dangerous climate change arrive for you?', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550124532000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'125851120', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"What slew rate would meet your demanding requirements, and why have the grid operators missed this vital point?"
See my post above re dispatchable power.
Use cases for dispatchable generators are:
Load matching - slow changes in power demand between, for example, day and night, require changes in supply too. Peak matching - short periods of time during which demand exceeds the power of load matching plants; generation capable of matching these peaks in demand is implemented through quick deployment of power by flexible sources.
Lead in times - periods during which an alternative source is employed to supplement the lead in time required by large coal or natural gas plants to reach full output; these alternative sources can be deployed in a matter of seconds or minutes to adapt to rapid shocks in demand or supply that cannot be satisfied by peak matching generators.
Frequency regulation or intermittent power sources - changes in the electricity output sent into the prison may change quality and stability of the transmission system itself because of a change in the frequency of the electricity transmitted; renewable sources such as wind and solar are intermittent and need flexible power sources to smooth out changes in energy production.
Back-up for base-load generators - nuclear power plants, for example, are equipped with nuclear reactor safety systems tat can stop the generation of electricity in less than a second in case of an emergency.
The demanding requirements are not mine, they arise out of the grid, the changing pattern of demand, the different rates at which generators can ramp up to meet that demand, and the changing patterns of supply from solar and wind. 
The different requirements for dispatchable power at different rates of dispatch require different power sources - from slow changes to match long term load, to peak matching and lead in time covering sources as well as combinations of these different rates of delivery. It horses for courses and a different horse for each stage.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550219043000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a change in the frequency of the electricity transmitted', u'effect': u'frequency regulation or intermittent power sources may change quality and stability of the transmission system itself'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'125867292', u'id': u'125893739', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'That is very concerning, as can be extrapolated from this; from a communication by James Hansen in 2018 regarding 2017 global surface temperature.

Dispatchable plants have different speeds at which their power can be dispatched.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550214606000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'125867139', u'id': u'125892470', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'(continued)"What about when the sun doesn't shine and the wind doesn't blow."
"'All this talk about ' you've got to have base load power stations ' is complete nonsense', says Dr Mark Diesendorf."
"His team at the University of New South wales ran 'thousands of computer' simulations correlating hourly power consumption data from the National Energy Market (NEM) in 2010, with the potential power generation of renewables, based on recorded weather data for the same year."
"He claims that a combination of existing technologies, including hydro and biofueled gas turbines, were able to supply the simulated NEM, even during 'peak-demand' on winter evenings following overcast days."
"'No single one does all the job...You probably need a mix of hydro, which may include off river pumped hydro, and possibly open cycle gas turbines', he said."
"'For those of us who work in the field, this is very straightforward now. But the barriers aren't primarily technological."
"Professor Blakers agrees. He says that Australia's future lies in solar and wind, with pumped hydro as a balancing source."
"'Pumped hydro is a 100 year old technology, completely off the shelf, and importantly you can get those pumped-hydro sites before 2022,' he says."
"'A recent study that we published shows that there 22,000 (potential) pumped hydro sites on the east coast. We only need 20 or 30 of them.'"
"A more connected energy grid."
"'The question isn't really a case of can you do it, it's a question of what cost,' says Dr Platt."
"Regardless of the energy mix, the researchers agree that a much greater capacity to transmit power across a connected grid is essential for a future dynamic energy system to work."
"It would be very, very good to join South Australia by transmission line directly to New South Wales... It would make the whole national electricity market a more stable system,' Dr Diesendorf says."
"'It's this long skinny system - 5,000 km long. Putting in one or two cross-links would benefit the whole system, but you can't do that overnight.'"
"None of these researchers are under any illusions that a transition to a more dynamic will be cheap."
"It will involve investment in infrastructure, across state borders, and a forward thinking approach from our political leaders."
"And leaving base load power in the past, they all agree, would be a good place to start."
"KEY POINTS"
"The 'base load' concept is misinterpreted and outdated."
"Demand varies hugely and energy production needs to be responsive."
"Hydro can be used to balance intermittent solar and wind."', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550210490000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'125867292', u'id': u'125891692', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CLeighton', u'text': u'I would expect the yearly increase in that number tobe accelerating over at least the next decade or two.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550123595000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101346019', u'in_reply_to': u'125849811', u'id': u'125850924', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Here's the paper which quantified the effect of loss of albedo from melting Arctic ice.

It means something else."
Though you say what it doesn't mean, you don't say what it does mean. What does "base load" mean in the context of electricity generation?
Seehttps://www.abc.net.au/news/science/2017-10-12/renewable-energy-baseload-power/9033336which asks"What is baseload power"
"Coal-fired power stations can take days to fire up from cold to full capacity and when demand slumps during off peak periods, shutting down isn't an option."
"So when these power plants were built in Australia, a market solution was created, says Professor Anthony Vassallo, Chair of Sustainable Energy Development at the University of Sydney."
"'In the 70s, to stop them having to turn off overnight, the regulators and operators offered very, very-low-cost electricity for consumers to run their hot-water systems, which in turn sustained the 'base load' on the power station,' he says."
"'base load' refers to the minimum level of output that these big power generators could go to, before they are turned off."
"But today as more and more renewables such as wind are feeding the grid, coal-fired power stations are often forced to pay to keep their turbines running when demand drops."
"'At night when wind in some areas is generating a lot (of power), it's the coal-fired power stations that don't get dispatched and the price can drop negative - below zero dollars - and so the (big) coal generators end up having to pay for people to take their electricity,' Professor Vassallo says."
"If not base load, then what?"
"Researchers argue that this 'base load' of supply from coal-fired power stations has been falsely translated as a baseline of consumer demand."
"'The idea of there being an average or 'base' electricity load, doesn't make sense. Let alone having this sort of big, slow-changing power station to meet that load' says CSIRO Energy Director Dr. Glenn Platt."
"Things are much more dynamic and the difference between the minimum and the peak amount of electricity we use is huge these days."
"Throughout the day, electricity demand peaks in the morning as people get ready for work, and again in the evening."
"But electricity use also changes across the year, with huge differences between hot summer days, when air-conditioners are at full blast, and mild sporing nights - with particular lows at unusual times like Christmas night."
"'Technology has moved on from base load, and now you want flexible power. And that's what demand management, batteries and pumped hydro is', says Professor Andrew Blakers, director of the ANU Centre for Sustainable Energy Systems."

Baseload is a strange concept.
BQENDTo my thinking it is surely the easiest concept - it is the minimum load on the grid.
The level below which demand does not go at any particular time.
So if you have a grid that supplies between 15 and 25GW on a 24hr cycle, your 'base load' is 15GW - no flexibility is required (in principle) - in reality it is a mix and match of what is available and at what price.
But the 'base load' itself is the easiest to serve.Hence in Australia, coal and CCGT for baseload and OCGT/Diesel/storage for peaking.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550187001000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'125866764', u'id': u'125887646', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'There have been images of herds of bloated beef cattle on the fence washed up and drowned by the sudden floods in my old stomping ground of Northwest Queensland. The higher we let global temperatures rise the greater the risk of them going really high as powerful amplifying feedbacks like ice melt and release of greenhouse gasses by melting permafrost strengthen.
Arctic ice melt alone over the last few decades caused a global warming equivalent to 25 percent of the forcing from atmospheric CO2. 
As the other half of the surface area of that summer ice goes away over the next several decades that already strong feedback will increase.
Add up all the other amplifying feedbacks and like China, the world will have trouble reining in the concentration of greenhouse gasses in the atmosphere.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550121537000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'arctic ice melt alone over the last few decades', u'effect': u'a global warming equivalent to 25 percent of the forcing from atmospheric co2'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'125847563', u'id': u'125850458', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'BQSTART

The joys of a busy life.
"The point is, like gas, it is a dispatchable supply as are older reactors in France and Germany."
As I pointed out previously, there is dispatchable power and there is dispatchable power, because some means of electricity generation and supply can be dispatched more quickly than others. Coal fired power stations, and the older reactors in France and Germany, are slow dispatchers.
"You can throttle down a CCGT gas plant but it becomes less efficient and emissions / kWhr get even higher."
This doesn't occur with throttling up in response to a sudden peak in demand but does it occur with throttling down during a continuation of the peak? Because the gas turbine part of the CCGT (combined cycle gas turbine plant) is a quick power dispatcher, it is used in response to a sudden peak or sharp increase in demand. If the peak once climbed proves to have a flat top, slower forms of dispatchable power such as nuclear reactors, gas thermal plants, wind farms and solar panels can be deployed allowing throttling down of the gas turbine part of the CCGT plant at a time of high demand with the excess heat still being used in the steam turbine part of the plant making no difference to the emissions per kWhr.
"Hence why we (and most developed nations) plan to use nuclear for baseload plus renewables."
I'm not sure where your "we" is, but in France they have 7,686 MW of very quickly dispatchable hydroelectric generation capacity, so they can respond very quickly to sudden increases in demand, the follow up with nuclear reactors, 4,000 MW of coal fired generation plus wind and solar panels when available.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550117568000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'some means of electricity generation and supply can be dispatched more quickly than others', u'effect': u'there is dispatchable power'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'125846092', u'id': u'125849547', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'It is the culmination. Until the next high ppm.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550117458000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13899889', u'in_reply_to': u'125849188', u'id': u'125849513', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CLeighton', u'text': u'It would be more honest to say that Australia will not meet Paris targetsunder either of your possible governments.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550173496000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101346019', u'id': u'125882547', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'As we contemplate whether or not to meet the Paris targets we might consider one threat we've already unleashed, and what we might still unleash.
Here's a paper published last month from PNAS titled: Four decades of Antarctic Ice Sheet mass balance from 1979–2017
BQSTART
We use updated drainage inventory, ice thickness, and ice velocity data to calculate the grounding line ice discharge of 176 basins draining the Antarctic Ice Sheet from 1979 to 2017. 
We compare the results with a surface mass balance model to deduce the ice sheet mass balance. The total mass loss increased from 40 ± 9 Gt/y in 1979–1990 to 50 ± 14 Gt/y in 1989–2000, 166 ± 18 Gt/y in 1999–2009, and 252 ± 26 Gt/y in 2009–2017.
During the entire period, the mass loss concentrated in areas closest to warm, salty, subsurface, circumpolar deep water (CDW), that is, consistent with enhanced polar westerlies pushing CDW toward Antarctica to melt its floating ice shelves, destabilize the glaciers, and raise sea level.
BQEND
https://www.pnas.org/content/116/4/1095
That is close to the 10 year doubling time which James Hansen noted in a 2016 paper would bring multimeter sea level rise in around 50 years.
Historically however, sea level rise has not followed a smooth, exponential curve, but has been marked by periods of rapid rise when sections of ice sheets collapsed, known as meltwater pulses. 
Here’s a graph of post glacial sea level rise from the last deglaciation http://vademecum.brandenberger.eu/grafiken/klima/post-glacial_sea_level.png
Those increased westerlies pushing already warm water into contact with ice shelves are an amplifying effect; we don’t have to wait for the ocean to warm . . .', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550171303000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'125881996', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Yeah, I wish it was fiction.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550116080000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'125848289', u'id': u'125849226', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CLeighton', u'text': u'We rely on you for the Atmospheric CO2 Concentration data from Hawaii.All else flows from that important number.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550115931000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101346019', u'in_reply_to': u'125848448', u'id': u'125849188', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'countryranger', u'text': u'Yes, I did miss the sarcasm, but having reread your earlier post, I now do appreciate the sarcasm.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550170388000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100633604', u'in_reply_to': u'125854133', u'id': u'125881785', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'loco_p_man', u'text': u'BQSTART

However, this study became dangerous the moment politicians used it to formulate policy.
11 years left... tick tock...', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550097836000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16662131', u'in_reply_to': u'125841791', u'id': u'125843722', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'Well anyone can make a mistake - it's a hypothesis, not an edict from the mount.
What was disappointing was how eagerly it was lapped up and anyone who raise a quizzical eyebrow was slapped down for their heresy.
I'm afraid that too many people see this as a polarised issue of sides that need to be 'supported' like a football team instead of as the highly complex technical issue that it is.What makes it worse is that Australia and the US have almost uniquely turned climate policy into a political argument.I don't think they realise that the rest of the world, by and large, has not.They are certainly unique in the OECD.
So if you produce figures or mention any of the countless technologies required in the background to a large scale RE system such as storage or grid strengthening or frequency control or, heaven forfend, an academic/expert paper you'll likely get labelled as "anti-renewables" or right wing by some impotently furious armchair 'environmentalist' who may as well be working for the fossil fuel lobby.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550093838000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'125838911', u'id': u'125841791', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'Indeed, people will cherry pick and 'believe' in any study which supports their preconceptions.
It's probably unattainable, but I suspect it will take government action to cede 'democratic' control and allow a scientific/technocratic body to coordinate our response to climate change via UN bodies incorporating the IPCC, DDPP and UNECE.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550103485000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'125843722', u'id': u'125846092', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'There is a base Carbon Tax in Europe but Germany, who has put a great effort into portraying itself as 'green', resist the imposition of one at a level which would actually impact its coal sector.So when France asked the EU to copy the UKs enhanced Carbon Tax system (Carbon Price Floor) and sign up to a UK style tax - (it is the UK CPF introduced in 2013 which is successfully pushing us off coal and onto nuclear and renewables) Germany refused.
Germany has already admitted that its plan to phase out nuclear has forced it not only to keep coal, but to open new coal plants and strip mines (one of which currently threatening an ancient forest) and so their emissions have not fallen - it would hurt their coal sector.
It could be argued that their phasing out of nuclear was an unprecedented subsidy to the coal sector. 
So despite these calls from President Macron, the German coalition government refuses to hold polluters accountable. “We say no to a price on CO2” said the CDU with a masterly piece of swapping nuclear for coal+renewable greenwashing that a surprising number of self styled environmentalists seem entirely at peace with.
https://energytransition.org/2018/05/german-government-rejects-french-call-for-greater-carbon-tax/', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550103047000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'125843870', u'id': u'125845930', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Nuclear like coal fired power stations currently in Australia is the slow last part of a cascade of measures battery storage, network power shifting, hydroelectric generation, gas turbines, and the last slow part, that load-follow at decreasing rates. The last two "load-follow" so slowly they are referred to as base load power.
I mentioned above the speed of hydro-electric power pumped storage or ordinary storage. I also mentioned the role of the 7,686 MW of pumped storage in France and am familiar with the similar geography.
I agree that the solution is mix of technologies each playing to their own strengths. Different places with different climates and geographies have their own individual different mix of different technologies.
At each stage of the response to a sudden increase in demand a different technology comes on line. Batteries such as the 100 MW one in South Australia are the first and fastest. Pumped hydro is not far behind by a matter of seconds. Queensland's 590 MW of pumped hydro in Wivenhoe Damis the first response to a sudden jump in demand. South Australia gets most of its water from the Murray River not very far above sea level. Much of the state is desert, so hydro stored or otherwise is not an option. Battery storage is their only option followed by gas turbines. Queensland has 3,477 MW of gas turbine capacity.
Australia is the size of Europe or mainland USA. The amounts of wind and sun varies from place to place. Most of the mainland is well provided for with sun. In the south winter winds off the southern ocean lows that bring cloud cover and rain coincide with times of high wind chill. Cold. clear frosty nights are rare but occur increasingly as global warming moves the lows further south in spring. This affected last years wheat crop.
Tasmania has large amounts of hydro and exports power across Bass Strait. During the severe El Nino of 2015-16 Tasmania's hydro dams ran dry at a time when their link to the mainland was damaged. On their north-west coast in particular they are very well suited to wind power. Stored hydro could be used in conjunction with this resource. Since 2016 the construction of a number of wind farms has started in Tasmania.
Baseload is a strange concept. Minimum demand occurs on pleasant days, cool pleasant nights, when there is plenty of solar and wind power to meet that demand. There are however cold still frosty nights with high demand and hot days as seen in the recent southern heatwaves with even greater demand. On such hot still summer days solar panels come into their own but other sources are needed to meet that Everest of demand peaks.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550150269000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'125859874', u'id': u'125866764', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'onthefence', u'text': u'BQSTART
Walsunda - But that load-following mode is much slower than hydro power and slower than gas turbine power.
BQEND
I see you still can't let the load-following thing go.I can't understand its central importance to you, but let's press on.
Current French Gen III nuclear slews at 65MW/min, (5%/min), the newer EPR slews at 80MW/min.For comparison, the AEMO planning assumption for new gas is 10MW/min for CCGT, 20MW/min for OCGT (although most are faster than that).That is, OCGT, whose main benefit is rapid response, needs to have a 20MW/min slew rate.
The new BoA lignite plants in Germany slew at 30MW/min. Their main selling point in Germany has been that their ultra-fast slew rate can track variations in wind output, making them a good match for wind and solar.
Here's a gushing RWE press release, explaining how Environment Minister Peter Altmaier and 400 assembled guests marvelled at the BoA lignite plant's enormous slew rate:
BQSTART
Efficient and highly flexible: BoA 2&3 makes important contribution to transforming German energy industry and climate protection RWE Press Release, 15 Aug 2012 
... Federal Minister for the Environment, Peter Altmaier and RWE CEO, Peter Terium gave an impressive demonstration of the plant’s flexibility to the over 400 guests. Instead of the usual start signal, they gave the order for a rapid reduction in electricity production. Within five minutes, the output of one unit was reduced by over 150 megawatts – and then equally rapidly restored, demonstrating the power station’s ability to offset the intermittency of wind and solar power.
BQEND
Decades-old nuclear can slew at twice that rate.
Dinorwig pumped storage hydro slews at 6800MW/min. It's an exceptional special-purpose capability. It's there to provide grid services that nothing else can. No one claims that nuclear (or anything else) will replace Dinorwig's function.
"Not as fast as Dinorwig" isn't the criterion for load-following.Nuclear works for load-following and frequency stabilisation in France, and it works for tracking wind variability in Germany. If Dinorwig is your reference point, you've misunderstood what load-following is.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550149125000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2490315', u'in_reply_to': u'125851634', u'id': u'125865798', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FredNurker', u'text': u'Many countries around the world are building new HELE coal power plants. description: There’s no way we’ll achieve the targets five years early without major policy changes, which are unlikely under the current government
og_fields.og:description: There’s no way we’ll achieve the targets five years early without major policy changes, which are unlikely under the current government
og_fields.og:title: Australia won’t meet the Paris targets despite what recent research claims | Bill Hare
text:
The Australian National University has been making headlines for its analysis that, with the current rate of renewable energy growth, Australia will achieve its Paris agreement targets five years early – by 2025. Unfortunately, after a careful review, we find their analysis doesn’t stack up.
The ANU briefing note has surprised, if not shocked, many in the expert and analytical community with detailed knowledge of Australia’s climate and energy policy.
Numerous international and national efforts to examine Australia’s climate and energy policy have all concluded that the government will not reach, on present policy settings, the 26-28% reduction from 2005 levels by 2030 it has put forward under the Paris agreement.
To achieve a 26% reduction below 2005 levels in national emissions – the lower end of Australia’s Paris agreement target – would require about a 75% penetration of renewables in the power sector by 2024, whereas the ANU scenario projects 50%, which is not enough to reach the Paris target.
The ANU briefing, possibly inadvertently, creates the impression that all that would be required is a continuation of the recent rate of renewable energy deployment. That is simply not the case, not without major policy interventions, which are unlikely – at least under the current government.
The government’s claim that the ANU briefing note shows it will achieve the Paris agreement targets “at a canter” is manifestly false. The rapid and continued rollout of renewable energy into the power sector assumed in the ANU briefing paper is something that the Australian government actually opposes.
The government’s policies are aimed at slowing the renewable energy rollout, and in particular maintaining coal in the power sector at any scale, which essentially contradicts the premises of the ANU paper.
The present large and increasing rollout in the utility sector is driven by the renewable energy target. Given that this expires in 2020, that specific economic incentive will disappear.
While the penetration of 50% renewables by 2025 may be plausible in the absence of further policy developments, it is not considered plausible that close to 90% penetration could be achieved by 2030 without substantial policy action.
Such reductions would also require phasing out coal almost completely from the power sector by 2030, which is clearly not supported by a federal government that is currently trying to promote more coal power, not less.
While the low cost of new renewable supply is also a clear driver, market barriers are already in evidence, along with grid connection issues that require active intervention.
As the ANU briefing note argues – and as is shown in peer reviewed studies (including by the authors of the briefing note) – achieving renewable energy penetration rates in the power sector at this scale by 2030 is technically and economically feasible.
However, there is a consensus in the expert community that these levels of penetration will not be achieved without further policy and grid development. An effective exit of coal from the power sector in Australia by 2030 would be one of the necessary steps in achieving this.
There is a very important role for renewable energy in the non-power generation sectors, such as industry, mining and agriculture. While the recent growth rate of renewables in Australia’s power sector has been high by world standards, it is also the case that the penetration of renewable energy into Australia’s total primary energy supply has not progressed rapidly and is relatively stagnant. This would need to change for Australia to meet the Paris agreement goals, and as a further major opportunity for the renewable industry.
The government’s own projections, updated most recently in December 2018 with present policies, show that by 2030, emissions will be at only 7% below 2005 levels.
The other explanation for the ANU’s anomalous finding is what appears to be a substantial underestimation of the ~70% of national emissions outside of the power sector – the emissions from direct combustion, transport, fugitives, agriculture, industrial processes, waste, and land use and forestry (LULUCF).
This is important, as the power sector only accounts for about 34% of national emissions (and declining), and overall emissions from these other sectors are growing.
The ANU assumes an average increase from these sectors of 2 MtCO2e per year. However, government projections indicate this increase is likely to average around 5.4 MtCO2e a year, on average, to 2024 or 2025, and then about 4.0 MtCO2e per year to 2030 (all from post 2018).
Given the underlying lack of policy, the historical growth rates and the trends in efficiency improvements of emissions in these sectors, the government projections look reasonable. The reduction rates the ANU paper assumes are far below any reasonable estimate.
Finally, it is also worth noting that the Paris agreement targets put forward by the Australian government are insufficient to meet the agreement’s 1.5°C long-term temperature goal. The Paris agreement would require reductions of 45- 60% by 2030 for the whole economy. 
• Bill Hare, a physicist and climate scientist, is the managing director of Climate Analytics

description: Letter: We are inspired that our children, spurred on by the noble actions of Greta Thunberg and other striking students, are making their voices heard, say 224 academics
og_fields.og:description: Letter: We are inspired that our children, spurred on by the noble actions of Greta Thunberg and other striking students, are making their voices heard, say 224 academics
og_fields.og:title: School climate strike children’s brave stand has our support | Letter
text:
We, the undersigned academics, stand in solidarity with the children going on school climate strike on 15 February, and with all those taking a stand for the future of the planet.
Nelson Mandela once said: “Our children are our greatest treasure. They are our future. Those who abuse them tear at the fabric of our society and weaken our nation.” Human planetary abuse is, in a very real sense, child neglect.
As many of us and other fellow academics have indicated previously in this newspaper (Letters, 27 October 2018), the scientific evidence of climate change is clear. For example, the summer of 2018 has been confirmed by the Met Office as the hottest on record for England. The heatwave adversely affected crops across Europe, with wheat and potato harvests reduced by one quarter, which in turn impacted upon food prices. Australia is similarly experiencing “hottest on record” weather events. As citizens across the globe will know and testify, many comparably disturbing examples could be given. We cannot nurture our children without Nature.
We are rapidly losing sea ice in the Arctic. The warming of the ocean, the melting of land ice and the ensuing rising sea levels will threaten coasts. In 2018, the European Drought Observatory noted a high deficit in soil moisture across Scotland, Ireland and much of northern Europe. This increases the risk of wildfires, such as those we saw across England in 2018. As well as posing a direct threat to life, fires produce toxic smoke, which is a significant health risk to young and old alike. Sir David Attenborough has warned: “If we don’t take action, the collapse of our civilisations and the extinction of much of the natural world is on the horizon.” Many other organisations, like Extinction Rebellion, are now working to bring the truth about the ecological crisis to the public’s attention.
It is with these tragic and desperate events in mind that we offer our full support to the students – some of whom may well aspire to be the academics of the future – who bravely plan to strike on 15 February to demand that the UK government takes climate action. They have every right to be angry about the future that we shall bequeath to them, if proportionate and urgent action is not taken. We are inspired that our children, spurred on by the noble actions of Greta Thunberg and many other striking students all around the world, are making their voices heard.Alison Green, PhD (Psychology), National Director (UK) ScientistsWarning.orgSir Tim Smit Co-Founder, Eden Project & Exec Chair Eden Project InternationalProfessor Kevin Anderson, Joint chair of Energy and Climate Change at Manchester and Uppsala UniversitiesProfessor Tony Watts OBEMolly Scott Cato MEP, Professor of Green Economics, University of RoehamptonChris Rapley CBE, Professor of Climate Science, UCLProfessor T. article_tags: [Environmental activism, Schools, Teaching, Truancy, Education, Protest, Climate change, Environment, Teacher Network]
description: Unions urge pupils not to walk out of class but some schools may adopt relaxed attitude
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Unions urge pupils not to walk out of class but some schools may adopt relaxed attitude
og_fields.og:title: Headteachers in a bind as pupils prepare to go on UK climate strike
text:
School leaders are having to wrestle with their consciences over pupils joining the nationwide climate strike to be held on Friday afternoon, caught between their duties as teachers and instincts as educators.
Thousands of the more than 8 million school pupils in the UK are expected to walk out of lessons to show their concern about the threat of escalating climate change.
Layla Moran, the Liberal Democrat education spokeswoman and a former science teacher, said she will be joining a rally in Oxford and urged school leaders to accommodate pupils who join the protests.
“As a former teacher I absolutely understand the frustrations that teachers and schools may have with these strikes. However, I would describe this as a teachable moment,” said Moran, the MP for Oxford West and Abingdon.
“I hope schools, colleges and universities see this in the positive light it is meant and equally hope those students act sensibly with making sure adults know where they are and making up the missed work.”
But the National Association of Head Teachers, which last week offered some support for those joining the strike, gave a more hard-headed assessment to its members as the day of the action approached.
“Pupils should only be out of school in exceptional circumstances. Whilst NAHT supports the right of young people to express themselves, first and foremost, pupils should be in school during term time,” the union said.
“While a school leader’s role is to ensure children attend school, are kept safe and receive a good quality of education, it is right that individual school leaders can decide how best to respond to any proposed protest by students in their school on Friday.”
Chris Keates, general secretary of the NASUWT teaching union, said young people were right to be concerned about climate change but warned that teachers had genuine safeguarding issues to consider.
“It’s not appropriate for pupils to just walk out of school. The young people organising this are potentially putting themselves and others at risk by simply walking out of school,” Keates said.
“Teachers take their responsibility for pupils welfare during the school day seriously and while they may have sympathy for the cause will not be able to condone pupils just walking out.
“A well-planned, accessible demonstration of young people at a weekend or during a holiday would enable thousands to participate and be a powerful protest.”
The Department for Education’s guidance says unauthorised absences must be recorded as part of safeguarding, but gives room for headteachers to approve absences in “exceptional circumstances”.
The organisers have written form letters for the parents of those wanting to take part, which argue that protesting qualifies as civic engagement and climate change is an exceptional circumstance.
With the strike taking place on the final day before half-term holidays in many parts of England, some schools may adopt a relaxed attitude. But others have already informed their students any absence will be noted as unauthorised.
Geoff Barton, a former secondary school headteacher who now leads the Association of School and College Leaders, said: “While we understand the strength of feeling over the very important issue of climate change, we would urge pupils against walking out of school on Friday.
“It is extremely disruptive for a school to have to deal with unauthorised absences and pupils will be missing out on important learning time.”
The day of action follows the example of Greta Thunberg, a 15-year-old Swedish schoolgirl who began protesting outside her country’s parliament in August. Her solo effort has since grown and spread to countries around the world including Germany and Australia.
In a letter to the Guardian, more than 200 UK academics said they offered “full support” to the school strikers. “They have every right to be angry about the future that we shall bequeath to them, if proportionate and urgent action is not taken,” it said.

Photograph: Nickolay Lamm/Courtesy Climate Central', u'height': u'3800'}}]
article_tags: [Environment, Florida, Climate change]
description: People tend to respond to immediate threats and financial consequences – and Florida’s coastal real estate may be on the cusp of delivering that harsh wake-up call
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: People tend to respond to immediate threats and financial consequences – and Florida’s coastal real estate may be on the cusp of delivering that harsh wake-up call
og_fields.og:title: Florida is drowning. Condos are still being built. Can't humans see the writing on the wall?
text:
I stood behind a worn shopping center outside of Crystal River, Florida, looking for the refuge where a hundred manatees were gathered for winter. I found them clustered in the emerald-colored spring, trying to enjoy a wedge of sunlight and avoid the hordes of people like me, boxing them in on kayaks and tour boats, leering over wooden decks. The nearby canals were lined with expensive homes and docks with jetskis. One manatee breached the water for a breath, and I could see the propeller scar on its back.
2018 was the second deadliest year on record for manatees. Like many of our coastal species, they’re vulnerable to habitat loss and warming seas, which are more hospitable to algal blooms and red tide. Science has given us the foresight we need to make decisions that will reduce the future suffering of other species and ourselves, but we don’t heed it. Why?
Studies show that humans don’t respond well to abstract projections. We overvalue short-term benefits, such as driving SUVs, burning coal and building waterfront real estate. We choose these extravagances even though they impede beneficial long-term outcomes, such as saving threatened species, or reducing the intensity of climate change.
Humans tend to respond to immediate threats and financial consequences – and coastal real estate, especially in Florida, may be on the cusp of delivering that harsh wake-up call. The peninsula has outsized exposure: nearly 2 million people live in coastal cities. On the list of the 20 urban areas in America that will suffer the most from rising seas, Florida has five: St Petersburg, Tampa, Miami, Miami Beach and Panama City. In 2016, Zillow predicted that one out of eight homes in Florida would be underwater by 2100, a loss of $413bn in property.
I flew into Miami in early December and the risk was visibly apparent from the airplane window. Aerial views of Miami and South Beach show high density construction on flat, sandy slivers of land. A recent National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) predicts Miami streets will flood every year by 2070.
South Beach was vibrant and populated, with mega-yachts docked in front of luxury homes, sorbet-colored art deco-era hotels rising a block from the water, cafes misting customers on the sidewalks, neon signs flashing bright in the night sky. But I wondered: given the forecasts, why are people still building new condominiums?
In Florida, you will see a bewildering mix of optimism, opportunism and denial in the real estate market: luxury condominiums going up in flood-prone South Beach, and property values rising in the vulnerable Keys, post-Hurricane Irma. And though the House of Representatives passed a bill to require real estate agents to disclose flood risks, the Senate has not reviewed it, and a culture of “systemic, fraudulent nondisclosure” persists in high flood risk areas.
You will see the massive benefits of privilege, and the way it allows a homeowner, particularly a second home owner, to afford the risk. You will see emerging issues like Miami’s climate gentrification, where previously low-income neighborhoods like Little Haiti are rising in value and under pressure from developers because of their higher ground, resulting in the displacement of people and place-based culture. Haitian playwright and bookstore owner Jan Mapou recently told a reporter: “Gentrification is coming forcefully: developers buying the major corners, raising the rents, forcing renters onto month-to-month leases … We’re not against development or modernization … but respect the people living there, their culture, their history.”
I spoke with a developer who wanted to remain anonymous, given business interests. He told me that he’s surprised that people are still buying, building and investing in coastal Florida. He estimated that a decade ago, only one in 10 buyers asked about the property elevation, or expressed concerns about rising seas. Today, nearly six of 10 ask and many decide not to buy in these same critical areas. “I’m worried we’re one bad storm away from a rush for the exits,” he told me.
I sought input from the environmental community as well. “Real estate is a huge economic driver here,” Laura Geselbracht, a senior marine scientist with the Nature Conservancy, said. “And it’s at risk from sea level rise. People don’t want to believe it. That’s a normal human condition – suspension of belief.
“If you’re not a millionaire and you own a property in a vulnerable area, it may be a wise decision to think about moving before the masses think about moving,” Geselbracht said. She also owns waterfront property on a canal in Fort Lauderdale, and is deeply invested in her community, but has cautioned her child not to expect the same lifestyle in the future.
She wonders why she doesn’t see more people of means in south Florida buying electric cars, getting solar panels and living more sustainably. “The quicker we take action, the better. We’ve got to be leaders so that we have a longer horizon of survival here,” she said. When she’s approached community leaders in the past, asking them to take steps toward sustainability, she often hears the same response: “Technology will solve it.”
It’s a high-stakes gamble. Consider innovative mitigation in action: raising roads, shoring up sea walls, adding pumps and drainage upgrades, beginning dredging projects, offering complex insurance structures. Proximity to these short-term solutions are not always pluses in a home buyer’s column, but acute reminders of vulnerability.
While Geselbracht is optimistic about developments like Orlando’s zero emissions goal, and Miami’s forward-looking Forever bond, she’s not ready to pin all her hopes on innovation. She also wonders about the fallacy of “safe” investments elsewhere. “There are air quality issues and forest fires out west, and extreme heat inland.”
I spoke with young farmers who recently decided to purchase a farm away from the coast. “As we looked for farmland to buy, we certainly thought hard about what the climate would be like in 10, 20, 30 years,” one of the owners of Ten Mothers Farm told me. “We knew we didn’t want to be near the coast, and we wondered whether even being in the south-east was a bad idea. Ultimately we decided that the most important thing was to be in a community that’s supportive and that we believe will be resilient.”
While baby boomers may be slow to adjust spending behavior to climate change, the Florida developer told me, millennials will not, and that shift will likely impact the market in the decade to come.
I grew up in two eastern North Carolina towns, Rocky Mount and Atlantic Beach, that have been bludgeoned by hurricanes. There, friends have real estate that falls into an increasingly common, and expensive, pattern: flood, repair, rebuild. Many are locked into this expensive, emotionally draining pattern because they can’t sell their homes, which have been flooded multiple times.
Browsing real estate in nearby New Bern, which was dramatically flooded by Hurricane Florence last year, reveals the terminology indicative of this practice. Homes are presented as a “blank canvas” and “waiting to be brought back to life”. There are optimistic takes, too, like “circumstances have created great potential”, and “great fishing”.
According to a 2018 report from the Union of Concerned Scientists, it’s not just houses that will flood, but also “roads, bridges, power plants, airports, ports, public buildings, military bases and other critical infrastructure along the coast”. Furthermore, the report indicates that financial markets have not accounted for this future downturn. The economic impact will be “staggering” and the window for towns to maintain creditworthiness and build resilience is “narrowing”.
The Union of Concerned Scientists point out that “nearly 175 communities nationwide can expect significant chronic flooding by 2045” and of those “nearly 40% – or 67 communities – currently have poverty levels above the national average”. States with areas of particular concern are North Carolina, Maryland and Louisiana, where a significant percentage of at-risk properties are owned by people of color.
The climate change-induced real estate crisis is imminent in the south, and it’s going to have a brutal impact on those who can’t afford new insurance, relocation, lowered property values, or bandages such as private sea walls. It will have an outsized impact on homeowners who live in flood zones or near over-heated superfund sites and toxic factories, and those who can’t afford to pay taxes on submerged land where they can no longer make a home.
I look at real estate listings and wonder, what if the places you love most are no longer a good investment? What if we’re so focused on denial, data and property that we fail to grasp the human side of the situation?
The moral imperative to act is not about salvaging expensive second homes on the waterfront. It is about taking responsibility for human action, helping frontline communities solve a complicated economic and cultural challenge, and doing what we can to help species whose survival is imperiled by our lack of foresight.
• This article was amended on 19 February 2019. We erroneously referred to Crystal Springs – we meant Crystal River. This has now been changed.

And, if you want to get really dark, you might have to be willing to deny the developing world the trappings of the developed one.', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550256765000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2313110', u'id': u'125917678', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dylan37', u'text': u'I guess part of the problem here, with getting the urgency of the message through, and generating some real action, is public apathy. Certainly in The West, we seem to be just tinkering around the edges, and our collective consciousness extends about as far as recycling, turning a light off when we’re not in a room, and maybe not running the tap while we brush our teeth. I include myself in this of course. I have a nagging sense that I should perhaps do more, and I imagine many others do too, but how many of us actually make the leap in lifestyle changes and habits that this problem apparently needs? Everyone I know has a car, often two, take at least a couple of international flights a year, powers their home, eats a full range of foods, purchased from global corporations with long and punitive supply chains, uses all available technology, and don’t live their lives with their carbon footprint front and centre in their mind. My peers were the ones who grew up voting for the Green party, holding fund raising events for wwf, demanding cycling lanes from their politicians and buying cars if we did who we chose for less and less fuel consumption. We renovated our houses (if we had some) with our ecological footprint in mind and started looking for options to save energy and fuel as well as realizing energy alternatives to get rid of coal AND nuclear power (as the waste of that is a problem for many, many more future generations). My generation stopped nuclear power plants in Germany. 
Yes, we still used and use too much plastic, yes we are still not living ideal lives. But compared to my parents and grandparents, who sometimes gathered all their dirt including old tyres and used motor oil and burned it in the garden, we were already a big improvement. It was us who had to deal with the problem of acidic rain - and 35 years ago I was a stroppy teenager still ... 
No, the youngsters did not invent Green ideas. They are working in a tradition of people who have already had high concern for the environment.

Let's hope that these kids set a better example and remind their parents constantly they they'd better not buy them any phones, tablets, laptops etc, definitely nothing made in China which has to be imported at a huge cost to the environment and don't even think about taking them on holiday abroad.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550255617000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16542913', u'id': u'125917315', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Blackswan77', u'text': u'Well what choice is there - it's either that or the apocalypse - or has the risk been exaggerated?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550256349000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12885021', u'in_reply_to': u'125916899', u'id': u'125917548', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'This cycle of protests was started by a school student in Sweden.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550256349000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'125917426', u'id': u'125917547', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'arnoldbird', u'text': u'I totally support this protest. The schools themselves, not just the authorities, need to start thinking a lot more seriously about global warming. It reminds me of Lionel Flowers’s environmental Facebook rant in Chapter 48 of Alun Wessler’s prodigious opus, ‘Odysseus’:
‘My thirteen-year old daughter, who is a clever and diligent student, has gained a place in an elite grammar school with a thriving Green Club and posters on the walls reminding students to put their rubbish into the recycling bins and turn off the lights when they leave the classrooms (but interestingly, not the air conditioners). I am sure that, if asked, the school's management would say they are progressive, environmentally responsible and really quite green (even if a lot of them do come to work by car in the world's least car-dependent city). However, the school has an exchange programme by which students from other continents spend a term being tortured in the Hong Kong education system, presumably working on the principle that suffering builds character. My wife insisted that our daughter take part in the scheme, because 'it's something that middle class families do'. Full stop. I was eventually forced to submit despite having severe misgivings about the value of the programme. And how right I was. We were forced to host two Australian Chinese girls for eight weeks in our tiny flat. These teenage antipodeans were rather bored, for three main reasons. Firstly, they were already from an Anglo Chinese background, so culturally there was little or nothing for them to learn in Hong Kong. Secondly they had already been to the city several times and one of them even had close family here. Thirdly, this was their fourth or fifth long-haul overseas trip of the year, and frankly by the age of fourteen they had got rather blasé about jetting around. I was hard pressed not to point out to the school that they were putting a lot of effort and resources into ensuring that spoilt kids with massive carbon footprints got a bit more spoilt and pumped out yet another few unnecessary tons of CO2. And this was supposed to be education.
The thing about this venture that drove me up the wall more than anything else was the question of why anybody thought this was a good idea. The organisers are highly educated and presumably the kind of intelligent people who keep abreast of international affairs. They know that guests like those in our household will almost certainly know Hong Kong well, and so it is a waste of time them coming, but much more crucially that it is a waste of energy which sets an appalling example for all the affluent young people in their care. The school managers, given that they are presumably not brain dead, absolutely have to know about the perils of global warming and the burning necessity for informed people in the twenty first century to start trying to do something to combat it. And yet they vigorously encourage their students to waste their time taking these frivolous flights around the world, in the full knowledge that every air ticket has a double carbon impact because it is an exchange programme, and for every local student flying to Australia there is an Australian counterpart flying the other way in the same week. In a very real sense, the school is acting like a coal-fired power station, churning out ton upon ton of carbon dioxide and encouraging impressionable young people to adopt this moronic behaviour as a lifelong habit. (Of course it should be said that this is not an entirely fair comparison. At least the dirty generating plant does actually produce something useful and worthwhile, such as the electric power for subway trains and hospitals.)’', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550255040000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it 's something that middle class families do", u'effect': u'my wife insisted that our daughter take part in the scheme'}, {u'cause': u'it is an exchange programme', u'effect': u'that every air ticket has a double carbon impact'}], u'author_id': u'2516115', u'id': u'125917144', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DisunitedKingdom', u'text': u'I'm not, I assure you.
The fact is, we were given predictions in my youth that turned out to be hopelessly inaccurate. By then, fortunately, we'll all just be a load of dusty old fossils.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550254966000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13921671', u'in_reply_to': u'125916708', u'id': u'125917124', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PeterOrmonde', u'text': u'Classless and free - young Lennonists, Mr M! 
Let's hope they do indeed earn from our experience. How not to be co-opted, bought-off and seduced by the sheepish idols of contentment. Beats watching a screen - doing face-time as they apparently say. 
I remember some of that experience - don't trust anyone over thirty fer instance. Truer than ever. 
I don't despair on any single one of these issues - after all we can change ... we have the smarts, the science and the spondooliks ... are we not Masters of the Universe? 
It's that last bit actually - the mastery business ... what we do just to feel comfortable ... bending nature to our needs and wants... reaping, sowing, that sort of thing ... along with the bulldozing, the logging, the overfishing, the holidays in Spain, all of it.
Simple bit of ecological arithmetic George - how many apex predators can a biosphere carry? What doesn't get eaten? It's the ultimate Plague of Locusts - and it's us.
And given the gluttonous, gobbling, wasteful way we live, we are the most apex of all - the greatest predators of all time. The wake of a smiling school child dwarfs the impact and carnage of a fully grown T Rex... you'd barely know they were here. No one's gonna forget us in a hurry. 
Not sure we're worth keeping around to be honest George... bit too toxic. I'm just saying that on behalf of the wrens I'm listening to.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550254966000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11608175', u'id': u'125917123', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'independent4', u'text': u'100%this generation has little time to redeem itself left', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550255559000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12920374', u'id': u'125917298', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'steverandomno', u'text': u'BQSTART

BQEND
If stopping doing those things is the solution, then many of those striking today will not accept it in later life, no matter what they say now. 
If you hope to promote environmentalism by denying them their desires, then good luck with that. But a good start, taking matters into your own hands, you are to be honoured for doing so.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550256281000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4079486', u'id': u'125917522', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'vtiman', u'text': u'Our generation is not just the UK', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550254966000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3991184', u'in_reply_to': u'125916869', u'id': u'125917122', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Robert Schwarz', u'text': u'Well if you "deprive" the children of the energy supply for all those SUVs and Porsches and frequent business flyers, it will improve their quality of life quite a lot.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550254958000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100138956', u'in_reply_to': u'125916935', u'id': u'125917119', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CforCynic', u'text': u'You start with a fallacy (" A century ago and you’d be making the same argument against women voting") and it goes downhill from there. 
I can think of more than a few 18 year olds that couldn't get their heads round the complexity of climate change during my time at university (Geoscience degree, by the way). Why do you assume that those younger than that have all the facts? 
The nonsense is all yours, and you wear your ignorance with (misplaced) pride.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550255553000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3949060', u'in_reply_to': u'125917041', u'id': u'125917296', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'OurPlanet', u'text': u'@Flashbleu I think @movingfinger has just placed his finger in one of his orifices.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550255551000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3540764', u'in_reply_to': u'125916568', u'id': u'125917294', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Blackswan77', u'text': u'Well i'm not (kinda playing Devil's advocate) - because i'm not fully convinced by the environmental message.
