Or has this march actually changed anything or brought anything new to the conversation?
If you want people's behaviour to change you don't skip work and go on a march, you start exhibiting the changes you want to see. If that's belittling then wear it.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550583053000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14599937', u'in_reply_to': u'126046556', u'id': u'126052778', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'Indeed, we were told that onshore wind is subsidy free, now the suppliers say that cannot operate them without ongoing subsidy.
It's not like they have to pay for the technologies required to counteract the intermittency of their supply.The truth is that no one, young or old, has designed a renewables only system, let alone one that would be practical.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582920000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'126043567', u'id': u'126052636', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Nicholas Hargreaves', u'text': u'.... and probably not protesting at the school gates at 3.30pm when they're getting picked up in an SUV, to be driven 500m home.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582836000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14733772', u'in_reply_to': u'126046960', u'id': u'126052523', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mark Hufton', u'text': u'Who is it about then?
If these structures are so ubiquitous how can I be exempted? Unless we're saying that only certain groups can be prejudiced and only certain members of those groups are capable of exercising prejudice?
Either way, nonsense.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582708000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14599937', u'in_reply_to': u'126045050', u'id': u'126052392', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Foreversummer', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
community standards.
Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582700000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'13063501', u'in_reply_to': u'126043385', u'id': u'126052385', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID7038625', u'text': u'You seem to be unable to detect the difference between scorn and realism.
If they had of had for instance a Walk to School week to protest, where they didn't just miss lessons, then I'd have been on board.But they didn't. 
What did they sacrifice? Nothing. Hence the cynicism.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582666000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3451383', u'in_reply_to': u'126051796', u'id': u'126052343', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AlternativeLogic', u'text': u'the waste per year from a small power station could fit in a couple of dustbin sized containers and buried with very little risk. There are no free lunches with power generation, but I prefer nuclear as a back-up for core load to coal.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582647000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14870711', u'in_reply_to': u'126048371', u'id': u'126052323', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'highlandpiper', u'text': u'BQSTART
I speak as a nan myself.
BQEND
Initially mis-read that as " a man myself " and wondered why the article was not given more prominence.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582616000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101318950', u'id': u'126052288', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fabcat21', u'text': u'She is not employed because she is sensible or speaks sense. She is employed to provoke page-hits. The more hits, the higher the advertising fees.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582537000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'she is sensible or speaks sense', u'effect': u'she is not employed'}], u'author_id': u'2384402', u'in_reply_to': u'126043000', u'id': u'126052200', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MoBro999', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
community standards.
Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582518000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'10196918', u'id': u'126052175', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fabcat21', u'text': u'Since the maths behind climate change is impenetrable to 99.99% of the population, that is a fairly astute jibe, although doubtless by accident.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582480000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2384402', u'in_reply_to': u'126043093', u'id': u'126052128', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AlternativeLogic', u'text': u'I don't think its either people pressure or international agreement which is needed - I think its both - as for the EU we'll see how they do, I don't have the blind faith in them as a force for good, which many seem to feel.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582439000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14870711', u'in_reply_to': u'126045602', u'id': u'126052075', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fabcat21', u'text': u'A strike is where people down tools and cease their normal occupation in order to protest. That is what they have done.Where is the impact of your pointless comment?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582428000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2384402', u'in_reply_to': u'126043268', u'id': u'126052065', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SFromNl', u'text': u'“so obviously orchestrated by adults“
They are not. Supported, yes.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582388000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17048054', u'in_reply_to': u'126051396', u'id': u'126052018', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fabcat21', u'text': u'They may have said that, but they had not studied the research from behavioural psychologists and neuroscientists that shows that the brain does not stop developing until into the 20s, and that teenagers simply lack the ability to process some kinds of information. You have to be careful not to let slogans determine policies wehere real issues are at stake, otherwise you make stupid decisions, such as allowing murder because the murderer had a right to their freedom of action. They do, but not without limits.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582352000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the murderer had a right to their freedom of action', u'effect': u'allowing murder'}], u'author_id': u'2384402', u'in_reply_to': u'126043612', u'id': u'126051966', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MoBro999', u'text': u'It reminds me of those articles when a child starts a multi-million pound business and halfway down the article its throws in it "precocious entrepreneur John 8, who's father is a senior executive at Bartle, Bogle and Hegarty says he first had the brainwave whilst... " 
:) :)', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582335000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10196918', u'in_reply_to': u'126051396', u'id': u'126051952', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Noutopia', u'text': u'No, I'm all for doing things but I'm a realist, I reckon I have one the lowest carbon footprints in the UK, I suppose I could lower it and be homeless and sleep in a doorway, but the fact is we are locked into catastrophic climate change now and the more renewable energy we create and use less fossil fuels makes climate change worse due to the aerosol effect global dimming produced by pollution, emissions of CO2 are rising, methane is spewing out of the permafrost that is melting etc, governments are basically doing nothing to mitigate climate change, this is the reality.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582266000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the aerosol effect global dimming produced by pollution', u'effect': u'climate change worse'}], u'author_id': u'10760557', u'in_reply_to': u'126047307', u'id': u'126051890', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fabcat21', u'text': u'How old a woman are you?What kind of nonsense is this post? Firstly, the Queen does not influence ecological planning or industrial strategy, and secondly you seem to think that being an old woman is somehow a bad thing - as if it were an insult. Better an old woman than a Middle-aged Trump, or a teenaged boy with a gun.I realise that it is a waste of breath, butr have you ever considered the possibility of a meriticracy that values intelligence, skills and achiuevement and is blind to gender, age or any other iurrlelevant attribute? Probably not, because you clearly lack merit.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582195000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'you clearly lack merit', u'effect': u'probably not'}], u'author_id': u'2384402', u'in_reply_to': u'126043725', u'id': u'126051801', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SFromNl', u'text': u'Yes, must be in their genes right? Anyway, parts of this Generation Me are beginning to question all this, it’s a shame that we answer their moral struggle with scorn.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582191000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17048054', u'in_reply_to': u'126051225', u'id': u'126051796', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'the_thoughtful_one', u'text': u'This is a common view that people have, I'm not so sure that it has much credence ... there is no doubt in the minds of people who work with sixth former's that a majority work hard and try their best in a highly competitive educational and job market to achieve the best grades and get in to a good university on the best course they can ... and I would say believe that the majority of these sixth formers are responsible hard working and a credit to their parents who have also invested in their children .. then however look at the industry of grade inflation brought about by the government which has monetised the whole graduate system, seduced all 18 year olds to apply for and spend £50,000 over three years on their education, introduced rules to keep all teenagers in full time education to the age of 18, failed to produce any credible apprenticeship system, the exam bodies themselves chasing improved grades each year, and schools needing to manipulate as far as they can improved grades to ward off special measures, and the universities now increasingly offering unconditional offers to students in sixth form to seduce them in to applying to their university, universities that were actuallly polytechnics and further education .. now given a paint job ... its all smoke and mirrors as is most of the UK ... but to label most sixth formers as wanting everything done for them .. I wouldn't go that far .. yes there are some that I will say ..', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582114000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12402044', u'in_reply_to': u'126046737', u'id': u'126051723', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fabcat21', u'text': u'Yes. But that is not the point. If you could halt the rise in consumption, and move rapidly to zero emisions, followed by reducing to a net negative footprint (not impossible if we can sequester Co2 in building materials and storage) than you can prevent.... perhaps... extinction. We are likely to closely approach or exceed that 4 deg C target and that means catastrophe. But if we can prevent a run-away effect than we may survive as a species. Or civilisation won't, but species survival is a worthwhile target.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550582023000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2384402', u'in_reply_to': u'126043778', u'id': u'126051639', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fabcat21', u'text': u'OK, good point, but what is the answer? An IQ test before voting? A test of knowledge and analytical skills first? Democracy is a lousy system, but it has so far managed to avoid the extremes of the dictatorships - look at European history for a lesson in what happens when the people have too little power, or ar steered by a 'charismatic' leader.The internet has given voice to what used to be the ignorant undercurrent - that is more or less how Brexit fell upon us. If we let that mob rule, we will simply collapse into chaos and anarchy. So no mob rule. But no group of people, be they ever so educated and honourable, are free of their own biases and agendas and they in the end rule rather than manage. Britain may have trouble with Brexit, but part of the reason is that power is more evenly distributed than on the Continent, where, for all the fine words about Liberty, the French have to set fire to the country to get attention from their elected King, and nobody expects to renogotiate a rule that has been dioscovered to be inappropriate.The best system so far is a meritocracy in powerful positions, moderated by a voting system that can boot them out and demands accountability. But it requires a good education system so that we all understand what is happening and an education, at taht, that includes maths and the skiulls to understand complex systems - not arts graduates who study politics.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550581831000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2384402', u'in_reply_to': u'126043814', u'id': u'126051450', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mark_MK', u'text': u'You seem to have completely ignored the impact of ‘green’ energy. There have been days in the last year when the U.K. has burned no hydrocarbons at all to meet its electrical needs. As more and more wind farms, tidal schemes and solar PV panels come on stream such days will become increasingly common. Also, with better insulation and lower consumption from many devices, our domestic electrical energy consumption is actually going down.It would be interesting to find out what the energy consumption was in the 1850s, bearing in mind that steam engines and open coal fires (two of the biggest users then) are appallingly inefficient compared with what has replaced them.
Lack of ‘trace elements’ (I suppose you mean rare earths) “pushes prices so high that economic collapse is inevitable” - puhlease! If prices go high then people will renew their phone less often, or just keep the old one. Since rare earth metals are valuable, it will be worth while for someone to set up a business extracting and recycling them from old devices. This used to happen with the gold-plated connectors on old computer boards, for example.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550581830000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14333987', u'in_reply_to': u'126047910', u'id': u'126051448', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: The UK’s kids protesting climate change were passionate, articulate and unafraid – those with old ideas need to get out of the way
og_fields.og:description: The UK’s kids protesting climate change were passionate, articulate and unafraid – those with old ideas need to get out of the way
og_fields.og:title: I can’t wait for the striking schoolchildren to grab the reins of power | Suzanne Moore
text:
This is a country for old men. So is the United States. Donald Trump is 72, and people are talking about Joe Biden running against him, aged 76; another possible presidential candidate, Bernie Sanders, is 77. In the UK, Jeremy Corbyn is 69; John McDonnell is 67; Vince Cable is 75. Jacob Rees-Mogg is 89. Only one of these ages is a lie. I guess you can work it out. Whatever happened to retiring? Why are these men considered to be at their political peak? I speak as a nan myself. Will I be running for office in 15 years’ time?
The blokes who govern the “free” world were brought into sharp relief by last week’s strike against climate change. My God, it was something. Suddenly in my house and on TV screens there were angry, informed teenage girls – and yes, it was mostly girls – talking about how we have just 12 years to do something. They were passionate, articulate and unafraid. Their energy was contagious. The fact they were having a fabulous time at a protest was inspiring and all the daft criticism about bunking off came from the zombie class such as Andrea Leadsom and various dullard rentagobs who don’t even seem to understand what school is: an hour a day of learning followed by hours of crowd control. But then I guess bunking off is as outre as running through fields of wheat for these alien suck-ups.
I am not pretending to be down with the kids – that is an entirely pointless exercise – but I do wonder about the way generational differences are playing out at the moment. The denunciation of the protests by the right wing is also a refusal to take climate change seriously. It is an entirely blinkered view. This “I’m all right, Jack” attitude is fine, I suppose, if you don’t have children or grandchildren who you would like to be able to breathe, and not be subject to the breakdown of society that climate change inevitably brings. What links those currently attacking the kids is not age but a certain political word view. Being rightwing makes you disturbingly ancient, somehow. Yes, I know the cliches about young folk being liberal until they are 30, when their heads take over from their hearts; or the US political writer Irving Kristol saying that a conservative “is a liberal mugged by reality”. The idea is that, as we get older, we become more conservative.
What actually seems to make people more conservative, from my observation, is becoming parents; what makes them fearful of change and social liberalism is the lack of money and choice, which brings a clinging to familiar structures. None of this is properly addressed by just shouting at old people to die soon, which is one of the tactics of some remainers. The divvying up of the generations ultimately amounts to some seemingly advocating a cull as the solution to Brexit: old, illiberal people voted for it and they will die out. But none of this speaks to the interdependence of generations, the fact that we live in an era in which adult children share parental homes, in which job opportunities have diminished in many areas of the country and further education has been decimated. Bringing the country together means just that. When youth bursts through, of course we cheer: whether its Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez in the US, or our own stroppy girls in the UK.
I cannot wait for these people to grab the reins of power. I neither want the closed and aged mindsets of the Tories banging on about wars they didn’t fight, nor the inflexibility of old Labour men obsessed with revolutions that produced dictators. Ageing is a fact, but open minds stay youthful. Those with old ideas need to get out of the way. Fast.

comments:
[{u'author': u'nigelwillemson', u'text': u'I got the information re the Maldives from the UN's own resources, and confirmed the Maldives above water existence by peer-reviewed searching of the internet. So, I am entitled to be sceptical over Climate Scientology over that climate period, no? And as for the disappearing ice: https://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/. I'll contribute to the GoFundMe for the art project!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550740822000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14173421', u'in_reply_to': u'126083512', u'id': u'126138186', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RealPol', u'text': u'The question is why to do so many eat so much meat?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550734432000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3751100', u'in_reply_to': u'126086502', u'id': u'126136248', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RealPol', u'text': u'Also the opening part of the article seems to suggest because art has not been talking about it (which I disagree with) there has been no debate on the subject at all.
BQSTART

BQEND
I can only suggest the author lives in some sort of bubble.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550734316000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'art has not been talking about it', u'effect': u'to suggest'}, {u'cause': u'this strategic exclusion of a topic from public debate over', u'effect': u'ignorance'}], u'author_id': u'3751100', u'in_reply_to': u'126098926', u'id': u'126136222', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Northernlass70', u'text': u'The Oxford English Dictionary's definition of 'art'
noun. 1mass noun The expression or application of human creative skill and imagination, typically in a visual form such as painting or sculpture, producing works to be appreciated primarily for their beauty or emotional power. 'the art of the Renaissance'
Whether you appreciate Banksy or Rembrandt, you, as human being, are able to create your own definitions of any piece of art and usually the artist will want you to direct you towards a particular thought process/ ideal or emotion. 
This ability of thought distinguishes us humans from nearly all of the natural world. 
How ironic that we are finally using art, one of histories greatest triggers innovation, to publicise and gain emotional recognition of the fact that climate change is REAL. 
15 years ago, when I really became aware of climate change, I was deemed eccentric, a doomster, and generally dismissed whenever I raised the c word. 
Now peers and friends agree with me that something is happening but don't see the horribly acute urgency. 
If art can again inspire change for the good of all and bring Earth's peril to the fore, bring it on.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550707279000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15608417', u'id': u'126129734', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GKB507', u'text': u'Slightly off topic, but according to today's Toronto Star, toilet paper made from recycled fibre constitutes less that 2% of toilet paper sales in the United States. (The US accounts for about 20% of global consumption) :https://www.thestar.com/business/2019/02/20/fight-climate-change-use-recycled-toilet-paper-and-less-of-it.html', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550705644000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11145063', u'id': u'126129136', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Graph of Arctic sea ice over the last 1,450 years which doesn’t include the last decade, if you tried to put recent years on there it would blow off the bottom of the chart a long ways.
Also the northern polar jet stream has been slowing due to the fact that the Arctic is warming around twice the rate of the rest of the planet which decreases the horizontal temperature gradient.
It has been getting stuck in wavy patterns bleeding heat north and cold south.
Hence the large high temperature anomalies in the Arctic and the "polar vortex" cooling parts of the US this winter.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550702685000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the fact that the arctic is warming around twice the rate of the rest of the planet which decreases the horizontal temperature gradient', u'effect': u'also the northern polar jet stream has been slowing'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'126125462', u'id': u'126127829', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Steve Erickson', u'text': u'As a botanist/restoration ecologist I not infrequently photograph rare species. Just when will it be gone?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550697091000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100629985', u'in_reply_to': u'126116429', u'id': u'126125462', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EconomicDeterminist', u'text': u'If Architecture is the pre-eminent art of enablement then it should enable us to combat climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550685260000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3270750', u'id': u'126121708', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'inertia', u'text': u'how many flights do you think they take a year?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550683723000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2461588', u'in_reply_to': u'126090532', u'id': u'126120685', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'thebowsie', u'text': u'BQSTART
When are world Governments and news papers going to start asking questions about how we start slowing down population growth?
BQEND
As others have pointed out, the numbers flatly contradict the idea that population growth is driving emissions.
The richest 10% of the world's population emit 50% of the CO2, and the poorest 50% emit 10%. You could reduce the world's population by half and be left with 90% of the problem.
Population growth does contribute to CO2 emissions, obviously, but the problem is chronic, whereas the intensity of consumption by the richest 10% is an acute threat to our climate.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550683079000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2484923', u'in_reply_to': u'126086162', u'id': u'126120196', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sharethewealth', u'text': u'BQSTART

I would have to say that revolution is the direct result of raised awareness.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550681316000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10133833', u'in_reply_to': u'126096272', u'id': u'126118841', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Looking through some gravel I had bought for my garden, I found fragments of ammonites, belemnites, gryphaea .... and small worked Mesolithic tools.
There were even a few rounded stone beads, with central holes drilled with flints.
The gravel may have come from one of the gravel pits in Oxfordshire, on a Thames river terrace, with the fossils coming from the Cotswold Jurassic.
I like to think of those folk, slowly creating those artefacts, producing strings of beads on a cord of some type.
They may have looked at those same fossils, already very ancient, and wondered about them.
Clearly, to make those beads, they were not just surviving, they had free time to do stuff they wanted to do.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550679041000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'126085283', u'id': u'126116476', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Warmer air contains more moisture, so some areas are seeing storms with heavier than usual snowfall, such as Boston in some of the last few years.
But if you look at the snow and ice that care about temperature the most, we have less river ice than we used to, less lake ice, less seasonal snow cover, less seasonally frozen ground, less perennially frozen ground, we have smaller glaciers, we have shrinking ice sheets, we have loss of sea ice. 
All the big pieces of snow and ice which care about temperature are shrinking.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550678992000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'126103768', u'id': u'126116429', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'crawfordcolo', u'text': u'Yep. In the early 80s there were assorted hedge-monkey crusty punks and moth-eaten hippies spreading information by photocopied and mimeographed pamphlets. That was our alternative to the UK press and three channel TV. People (journos included) can't be arsed and it's even more depressing than the 80s when you consider the resources that are available.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550665495000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13742367', u'in_reply_to': u'126092738', u'id': u'126099818', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dave6723', u'text': u'You need science as well as art. For example, one of the problems with Valdez was that they used the wrong detergent in the clean-up operation. On that was suited to the warm water and muddy/sandy shores of the Gulf of Mexico, not cold, rocky, gravelly shores. I recall people in the know in the UK saying WTF are they doing? It's much more like our shoreline and we've banned that stuff because in our conditions, it does more harm than good. Also, on some substrates, the least bad thing is just to let the oil be buried. Life is so slow in the Arctic that it takes decades to recolonise a cleared beach. In Louisiana, it would be recolonised within a year.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550665000000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'in our conditions it does more harm than good', u'effect': u"and we 've banned that stuff"}], u'author_id': u'18522661', u'id': u'126099161', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Guy_Denning', u'text': u'BQSTART
Quite a few artists make work about climate change, the articles idea they or haven't been is rather silly.
BQEND
Agreed. I'll accept that the art institutions of state might've only recently joined in on the eco art, and that the arts media (here and elsewhere) generally give more attention to artists (or their galleries) that have the PR connections to punt their press releases, than to artists (particularly graffiti and street artists) who've been on this message and mission for years. When you start an article with "After too long a silence, art is finally tackling global warming. "I'd have to politely reply "Do a bit more research beyond the filing cabinet section of 'U' for 'usual suspects'"There is an impolite reply but I'm too old and sensible for that sort of behaviour nowadays.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550664790000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13742367', u'in_reply_to': u'126089357', u'id': u'126098926', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dave6723', u'text': u'The problem is CO2 intensity, not population. We've increased emissions per head far faster than population growth. Population growth is only 5% of the problem. The other 95% is what those people do. Our carbon intensity has increased twenty-fold. Rich-world emissions-intensity increases have vastly exceeded third world population growth for decades. It will be much easier to shave a few tens of percent off that than to shave a few tens of percent off the population.
1 billion people in 1804, about 7.6 billion today. CO2 emissions have increased by a factor of 150, since 1850.
150 ÷ 7.6 = 19.74. 1 ÷ 19.74 = 5.07%. And that's being generous to population growth's contribution by assuming no increase in emissions per head between 1804 and 1850.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550664113000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18522661', u'in_reply_to': u'126086162', u'id': u'126098129', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'beechen', u'text': u'There are a huge number of people the world over who do and have done their bit to try and highlight or reduce the effects of climate change. This has been through a range of different strategies. Unfortunately their efforts do not receive any publicity and it is only the likes of the famous people as for example in this article, whose work is given media coverage. Art and revolution have a lovely history. To be specific, I believe the revolution happens first and then history decides afterwards whose art meant anything relevant. That said, I have never heard of a revolution of any kind driven or won by either "raising awareness" or propaganda which is what political art is albeit on behalf of an individual. Talk is cheap.
You are in the business of information. Art is subjective and not specifically for the purpose of education. Climate change is an issue that can only be understood or discussed using objective principles. "An Inconvenient Truth."
Bonus: if international and personal relationships are fundamental to peace and happiness, it's probably a good idea to relate over objective rather subjective issues. Have you heard? Vote the Tories out for that alone.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550658826000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1347038', u'id': u'126092554', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Slobodan Beardevitch', u'text': u'Both art and science have to be mainstream in order to be effective in the fight against climate change. They have to be put in the forefront of collective consciousness. If they are denied the mainstream, then scientific certainties will continue to be wilfully dismissed as fake, and art will be regarded as emotional fluff. 
What gets mainstreamed or not, is entirely dependent on the ideology and belief system of the time. In these times, if something can't be monetised or exploited, it will not even get a second glance by those who are best positioned to do something about the mitigation of climate change.
Those who do have influence tend to be government and the media, and if they are in an ideological lockstep with each other, then regrettably that is what will persist.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550658697000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18397584', u'id': u'126092426', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Glozboy', u'text': u'You know they didn't actually wrap the glacier in foil, right?', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550658412000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3349583', u'in_reply_to': u'126091061', u'id': u'126092169', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'stoneofsilence', u'text': u'The greatest threat to the planet is the linear economy that is premised on waste and more waste - as well as pollution. Who can walk past an ATM without salivating :-). The answer is the circular economy and the use of the linear economy to promote and eventually be replaced by the green economy. Wrapping things seems in a way to be linked to our consumerist psyche.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550657585000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2935579', u'id': u'126091411', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'Last two stanzas from Joni Mitchell's song Woodstock.

The resulting art may turn out to be more powerful in addressing our current situation than any intention-based, consciously-directed art strategy.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550657091000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100102727', u'id': u'126091015', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kuaile', u'text': u'Western man's relationship with modern and traditional art is also a big driver of climate change - it's part of an indulgent and wasteful mindset that demands gratification and will spend whatever it needs and waste whatever it wants to get it.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550656757000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2528978', u'id': u'126090772', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rorymurray', u'text': u'Surely not quite that simple. Madge has a project to preserve the Oceans.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550656472000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101306448', u'id': u'126090532', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'colinizod', u'text': u'What and no mention of Cape Farewell ?www.capefarewell.com The original cultural approach to climate change started by David Buckland with a first voyage of artists and scientists to the Arctic in 2003 and still at it', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550656328000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3033617', u'id': u'126090417', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BioyCasares', u'text': u'Why no mention of Liberate Tate, the brave campaigners who battled the Tate over a period of years to remove the art washing sponsorship of BP? Long before activism became a fashionable and overused term in the art world, they made creative, visually memorable interventions and received little support from their fellow artists. And they succeeded!', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550656075000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11766139', u'id': u'126090202', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MartynWasp', u'text': u'Reminds me of the cartoon: "What if it's a big hoax and we create a better world for nothing".', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550655453000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16630511', u'in_reply_to': u'126086832', u'id': u'126089646', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gruniadreader666', u'text': u'Quite a few artists make work about climate change, the articles idea they or haven't been is rather silly.
The real problem is while the message was once rather radical, now it isn't and the majority of cooperations and politicians save Americas ideological right agree it a problem and are trying to tackle it, for example most car manufacturers are researching electric cars or other alternatives to petrol. 
The problem is capitalism, as Marx said good businesses that spend money solving social issues are naturally get punished by businesses that don't. 
However the idea many here seem to take, which is Marx's the complete abandonment of capitalism, is a little unreasonable, while the complete revolution of human society with the death of millions may well be possible, no one has yet to achieve it.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550655110000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4076170', u'in_reply_to': u'126085452', u'id': u'126089357', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jodro', u'text': u'Great to see these initiatives, and the silence on the art front has indeed been puzzling, and galling. I wasn't aware of the link with art sponsership by fossil fuel companies, but I doubt very much that it is the main reason, because the silence in the music community has also been equally deafening, and I don't think that's in any way linked to fossil fuel sponsership, though I stand corrected if anyone has information to the contrary. 
I simply cannot believe that 99% of bands and singers continue to make music as usual, and in the case of pop and rap with completely narcissistic lyrics, while we have several acute way-of-life-changing crises going on. It feels very very pathetic to have people singing 'I lost you, please come back,' when we're at risk of losing the planet. I work in the music industry, and have made this point several times over, only to be met with blank stares. 
So I think it reflects a deeper, cultural malaise, in which alternative and reality-based thinking, and artistic expressions of this, have become taboo and uncool. It's probably another side-effect of the neoliberal dogma that has overtaken the Western world, ever since the collapse of the eastern bloc, leading to a manufactured consent and self-imposed censorship. 
There are a few signs of this changing, with things like these anti-climate change demonstrations by kids and Excinction Rebellion going mainstream, and hopefully this will increasingly be reflected in the art and entertainment industries as well. But we need more, much more...', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550654847000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the silence in the music community has also been equally deafening', u'effect': u"i doubt very much that it is the main reason and i do n't think that 's in any way linked to fossil fuel sponsership"}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'a manufactured consent and self imposed censorship'}], u'author_id': u'2110077', u'id': u'126089131', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Rattenfaenger', u'text': u'I think that the premise for this article, "After too long a silence, art is finally tackling global warming" , is open to question. Reality asks for artistic body bags for the UK's paupers - but better say nothing, the issue would be called pornographic.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550652696000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11673479', u'id': u'126087373', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shotcricket', u'text': u'If you focused on the human imagine need & its impact on the Earth in terms of sustainability you/me would be well on the way to resolving the permanent damage done to the Planet & the rest of the fauna/flora that reside therein.
Remember we are just one of the diverse residents on this wondrous Planet & yet we still have stupid old men in China & similar who believe the Tigers tooth, bones are of some value to their life, sex drive, Elephants/Rhinos? well just what are those tusks for & do they need them, bile painfully extracted from bears for obvious reasons, old men who must believe the world is their oyster or even lobster. 
But in truth the only way to slow/cut the demands of the human population is to cut the number of humans on the planet...we could begin with those who think the ruthless & painful & little doubt terrifying death of other inhabitants of this Planet is their right...for no apparent reason.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1550652691000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16059320', u'id': u'126087368', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CarlosVonBosch', u'text': u'We don't have a population growth problem, we have a problem with capitalism. description: After too long a silence, art is finally tackling global warming. Here are the big players – including the photographer who’s lighting up Alaska
og_fields.og:description: After too long a silence, art is finally tackling global warming. Here are the big players – including the photographer who’s lighting up Alaska
og_fields.og:title: From foil-wrapped glaciers to the Alpine storm cyclist: the artists fighting climate change
text:
In 1975, photographer Michel Comte stood up before scientists, business leaders and politicians at the Club of Rome to deliver a speech about the climate disaster he believed was on the horizon. Back then, he was still a student, and a little nervous – but he could sense the future. Now, Comte’s recent works incorporating black carbon fallout from the jet stream, shown in Rome, Milan and Hong Kong, prove just how right he was to speak out.
Comte’s message was echoed last week in the UK, when thousands of schoolchildren – inspired by 16-year-old climate activist Greta Thunberg – took to the streets to pressure the government into taking action on climate change. Like Comte, they have seen a bleak future ahead and are speaking out.
Sadly, that hasn’t been the case for most artistic and cultural institutions, which have spent the last few decades responding to climate change with little more than silence. They have been dangerously complicit in desensitising society to what’s really at stake.
It hasn’t always been this way. In the mid-90s, when a post-Chernobyl generation made its voice heard, the ecological protest movement was nurtured by critical theatre, radical art shows, public debate and avant garde music. Then something changed. In response to the backlash against fossil fuels, major energy suppliers became involved with arts sponsorship. This was no harmless philanthropy. Parallel to the rise of the blockbuster exhibition the importance of Shell and BP to the artistic budget of arts centres grew, to a point where many major national institutions were on the payroll of the fossil fuel giants. Some still are today.
For decades arts institutions have effectively engaged in self-censorship, denying us a debate on fossil fuels
But even for those who have freed themselves of it (or exchanged them for carmakers), the damage to a generation has been done. For decades arts institutions have effectively engaged in self-censorship to pay for their productions, putting on amazing programming and covering critical topics, as long as it wasn’t a thorough debate of our addiction to fossil fuels. This strategic exclusion of a topic from public debate over more than a generation has led to ignorance, with repercussions in education, academic and public life.
But there is hope in the air. Tate Modern have an Olafur Eliasson retrospective scheduled for this summer – his Ice Watch project was recently invited to melt away outside the museum, with the carbon impact of each block accounted for. As for Comte, he is about to board a sailing boat for a challenging passage to the Arctic, creating a monumental light installation calling for us to change our ways before it’s too late. If we allow more artists such as these to become part of the conversation, we will have a culture fit for the generation of children who took to our streets.
Nuclear fallout, rising sea levels and … nail clippingsWhen artist Yi Dai opened her first solo show in Berlin, she received rapturous reviews praising her subtle and intelligent coverage of environmental topics. Misfits, Offcuts and Castaways, in 2016, was an urgent statement reflecting on the aftereffects of nuclear fallout and rising sea temperatures, and the fragility of our ecosystem. Her exhibition was as much a personal account of her experience on the Marshall Islands as it was a call to action following the then-warmest winter in recorded history. Her show, Discarded… During My 20s (at House of Egorn in Berlin until 23 February), explores the subject of the human body: the artist juxtaposes bodily remains – hair, nail clippings, blood – with construction materials such as steel, concrete and glass that surround, contain, or reflect our bodies.
Sailing to the Arctic for a climate vigilWavelength Foundation was formed on a sailing boat in late 2017 by an international group of journalists, writers, environmentalists, cultural workers, artists and scientists. One of the foundation’s fundamental principles is that a rich and meaningful cultural engagement with nature is needed to readjust their lost relationship. Comte will soon set sail to the Arctic with the foundation for his large-scale 3D-mapping light installation Black Light, inviting sailors from around the globe to join his monumental climate vigil. Meanwhile, the foundation’s Change Maker scheme is helping to build a sustainable arts and culture centre in South America, to bring the opportunities of a circular economy to the lives of children and younger people looking to escape the cycle of poverty.
Remembering Earth before the cataclysmsParis-based artist Nadine Rotem-Stibbe explores environmental issues with a keen eye for design. Her installation In Loving Memory, 2018, 0.8°C, a collaboration with Ryan Cherewaty, can be found at an abandoned building site at the Ebbingekwartier of Groningen, the Netherlands. It takes a part mocking, part melancholic view of our time, looking back from a fictitious (yet by no means unrealistic) future in which a large cache of archaeological objects has been uncovered in the Trans-European floodplain. The artefacts offer an unprecedented look into human life in 2018, prior to the great cataclysms that struck. There is a profound obsession with objects created from the industrial processing of complex carbon-chain polymers – plastics – an industry that was a key factor in heavily increasing carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. These objects seem to have survived extreme climate changes and offer a glimpse into our perplexing culture. 
The art school on the edge of the worldPerched on the shore of a sea loch and overlooking the Minch and the hills of Harris and Skye, Lews Castle College in the Outer Hebrides has been referred to as the “art school on the edge of the world.” Sustainability is a key element to the teaching, with students responding to the environment and the unique wilderness of the unusual location. The college hosts talks from practitioners across a range of areas, from marine biologists and archaeologists to traditional makers working with natural materials. Part of the college building is the site of a recently commissioned light installation by Finnish artists Timo Aho and Pekka Niittyvirta, which interacts with the tidal changes, activating on high tide. The work provides a visual reference of future sea level rises and explores the catastrophic long-term impact of our relationship with nature.
Mountain biking through our tumultuous weatherTales of Change brings together stories of how climate change is impacting communities in some of the planet’s most iconic mountain ranges. Its protagonist, Florian Reber, cycled across the Alps, starting in Trieste on the Adriatic coast and arriving in Cannes, at the Mediterranean Sea. Along the way, he talked with farmers, foresters, conservationists, tourism experts, alpinists and professional athletes, psychologists, writers and journalists about climate change. Periods of tumultuous weather extremes are the consistent findings, including a pronounced drought that left many rivers and sources in the southern Dolomites dried out. This was followed by the strongest föhn storms in recent years, causing record temperatures in October 2018. Next came torrential rain and strong winds brought about by cyclone Vaia, uprooting thousands of trees and causing casualties. While this trip involved cycling 1,180 miles, climbing more than 35,000 vertical metres and mastering two dozen mountain passes in winter, the intrepid explorer is now getting ready to widen his reach towardsthe Rocky Mountains and Himalayas. The project has been on display in Switzerland and Italy but, like Reber, is constantly moving. 
Solar robots transforming snow back into glaciersHoused in Barcelona’s magnificent historical pavilion Sant Cosme y Sant Damià, Quo Artis is an international non-profit organisation dedicated to advancing the dialogue between arts, science and technology. Recent activity includes Glaciator, an art installation in Antarctica composed of solar robots that help to compact and crystallise the snow by turning it into ice, then adhering it to the glacier mass. As glacial melting is one of the most alarming effects of global warming, the mission of these robots is to accelerate the ice formation process, allowing glaciers to regain the mass they have lost as a result of the thaw. 
The old furniture factory where ‘waste is a failure of the imagination’This 1930s furniture factory, in southern Sweden, is being turned into one of the most exciting places for interdisciplinary research and innovation in sustainability. The brainchild of former gallerist David Risley, the hub brings culture together with science, philosophy, free thinking and business, and is scheduled to open in summer 2020. With more than 12,000 square metres of open-plan space set over several floors, Funkisfabriken could become a test bed for new sustainable approaches. “Waste is a failure of imagination,” reads its founding slogan. Located a short walk from the botanist Carl Linnaeus’s house and garden, the space will feature an array of labs (wet, dry, clean and dirty), an urban farm, a circular economy centre, and conference facility, exhibition spaces and sculpture parks – not to mention a hotel, indoor garden and a zero-waste restaurant set up by Doug McMaster of the Brighton restaurant Silo.

description: William Happer, a physicist who has suggested higher levels of carbon dioxide are beneficial, would be on committee
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: William Happer, a physicist who has suggested higher levels of carbon dioxide are beneficial, would be on committee
og_fields.og:title: White House climate change panel to include man who touted emissions
text:
The White House is planning to assess how climate change impacts national security and will involve a prominent doubter of the scientific consensus that manmade warming is putting the US at risk.
Donald Trump’s staff have drafted an executive order to establish a Presidential Committee on Climate Security, according to reports from the Washington Post and New York Times. It would include senior aide William Happer, a Princeton physicist who has suggested – in conflict with the vast majority of climate scientists – that higher levels of carbon dioxide are beneficial.
A recent assessment from the national intelligence director, Daniel Coats, called climate change a significant security risk, the Post noted.
Under former president Barack Obama in 2014, the Pentagon said climate change posed “immediate risks” to national security and laid out plans for boosting resilience and readiness as seas rise, disasters intensify and drought exacerbates instability around the world.
However, Trump and his cabinet have dismissed several federal government reports that said climate change is worsening and already threatens public health and the economy in the US.
“I don’t believe it,” Trump said in November. His agencies have suggested that the reports are based on the worst-case scenario, although the scientists who wrote them said they project what could happen based on current trends.
Trump’s former environment administrator, Scott Pruitt, long planned to host debates on climate science but was thwarted by some White House staff. Happer helped create a list of possible participants for that debate, according to emails obtained under the Freedom of Information Act.
In 2017, Happer told the Scientist that climate change research has become a “cult movement”.

Travelling between cities now and 20 years ago is not the same. For one, roads now are surrounded by development instead of fields. This means that insects, that used to travel across are not there anymore because their habitats are gone. The distinction is important because the solution needs to tackle the problem and not perceived problems that may not be relevant. As a budding entomologist i took great interest I always checked the radiator grill and the windscreen to see if anything interesting had been killed. Most of the kills were either flies (blow flies, "house flies" and the odd syrphid) or wasps. These guys don't travel huge distances for no reason, so if you get rid of fields within a few hundred meters of a highway you are unlikely to get many. As for the insect declines, most of the data is skewed to agri fields. description: Exclusive: climate change linked to ‘astonishing’ drop in Australian moth numbers, the key food source for possums while breeding
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Exclusive: climate change linked to ‘astonishing’ drop in Australian moth numbers, the key food source for possums while breeding
og_fields.og:title: Decline in bogong moth numbers leaves mountain pygmy possums starving
text:
Numbers of unique Australian moths that migrate in their billions to alpine areas have crashed, ecologists say, putting extra pressure on the endangered mountain pygmy possum.
Scientists believe the “astonishing” drop in bogong moth numbers is linked to climate change and recent droughts in areas where the moths breed.
At the same time checks on the endangered mountain pygmy possum, which exists only in Australia’s alpine regions, have revealed dead litters in the pouches of females. The moths are a key food source for the possums as they wake from hibernation.
In 2018, scientists revealed bogong moths were the only known insect to use the earth’s magnetic field to help them navigate from grasslands in northern New South Wales and southern Queensland – sometimes at distances of 1,000km. Around two billion moths are estimated to make the journey.
The ecologist Dr Ken Green has been monitoring bogong moths for 40 years. He said: “Last summer numbers were atrocious. It was not just really bad, it was the worst I had ever seen. Now this year it’s got even worse.”
The moths find caves and cracks in boulders to hide away in a torpor state. A cave at Mount Gingera, near Canberra, has been known to house millions of the moths but last month Green and colleagues counted just three individuals. Searches of about 50 known sites have turned up similar catastrophic absences.
“They haven’t just declined. They’ve gone,” he said. “We have done mountains from down to the Victorian border all the way to Canberra. We have checked every cave we know.”
A site at South Ramshead in the Snowy Mountains in New South Wales had just 1,000 moths last year. “That is very, very low,” says Green.
“This year we found just six moths. Last week we went back and there were none.”
Green believes the cause of the crash is drought in the moth’s breeding areas. The Bureau of Meteorology has said the drought was exceptional in those areas, but noted there had been similar dry periods in the 1960s and earlier. 
Dean Heinze, an associate at Latrobe University, has been monitoring and researching mountain pygmy possums since the early 1990s. The possum populations are spread across Kosciuszko national park in New South Wales, and in Victoria at Mount Bogong, Mount Higginbotham and Mount Buller.
As the possums emerge from hibernation in September and October, the moths are a key food source as they breed and raise young.
“Bogong moths are an incredible food source and very high in protein. Last year we found that some populations of possums were losing litters. It’s happening again this year. We think that the fewer moths means the possums are carrying less weight and losing the litters.”
In recent weeks Heinze has visited about 12 locations in Victoria and discovered dead litters in female pouches at “most of the sites.”
“It’s a widespread event,” he said. “I inspect the reproductive system of the animal and I look in their pouch to see how many young there are. I have been opening pouches and discovering dead and decomposing young ... For some, the young have been dead for days.
“The concern is that over time, if this happens more frequently we will see declines in the adult population as well. And this is the second year that they have lost litters. The litmus test will be next season.”
Around Mount Buller in Victoria, the possum habitat is fragmented by ski resorts. Captive breeding and release programs have been used to keep numbers up.
“We have put a huge effort into the population at Mount Buller,” says Heinze. “We have brought the population back from the brink and now we have this happening. I’m optimistic, but if we get more of this then it doesn’t look good. Here we are dealing with a species that only occurs in the alps, but what’s impacting it is happening hundreds of kilometres away.”
In 2016, a national recovery plan was agreed for the possum, outlining multiple threats including habitat degradation, predation by invasive cats and foxes and climate change.
A study published in October 2018 and led by scientists at the New South Wales Office of Environment and Heritage looked at the climate change threats to the possums and the moths. The study suggested the moths had a “reduced survival in a warmer world” and this would “likely further affect survival” of the possums.
Prof Lesley Hughes, an ecologist at Macquarie University and councillor at the Climate Council of Australia, said the potential role of climate change in the decline of the moths and possums were what ecologists and climate scientists had predicted.
“Unfortunately the general predictions of the ecological risks of climate change are now turning into observations for particular species. And it should be no surprise we are seeing these impacts in the alpine zone, long recognised as one of the most vulnerable ecosystems to climate risks.
“Sometimes these changes can appear to happen abruptly – one year there are millions of moths and the next almost none. This shows how particular extreme events, such as droughts or severe bushfires, can suddenly tip a species over the edge, with flow-on effects to others in the ecosystem.”
The environment minister, Melissa Price, said she was aware of the reports of low bogong moth numbers and the government was working with a leading possum researcher “to understand the potential toll that reduced number of moths may be having on the species”.
The removal of feral cats and foxes in Kosciusko national park was helping possum protection, she said, and two government-backed projects were tackling weed infestations, building resilience to climate change, and managing loss of genetic diversity among possums in the Victorian Alpine region.
Victoria’s Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning spokesperson Adrian Moorrees said the reduction in moths “is likely to be due to recent droughts” in NSW and Queensland.
He said tools and processes were being developed “to better monitor and predict the impact of bogong moth populations on endangered mountain pygmy possums.”
A spokesperson for the NSW Office of Environment and Heritage said no litter deaths were reported in NSW possum populations, but the drought was believed to have impacted most species.
He said when moth numbers were low, possums turned to other food sources, including insects, fruits and nectar, adding “OEH will continue to implement the species recovery plans for the mountain pygmy possum.”

So are those journalists willing participants in the con job or are they just very stupid.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1551144243000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12298649', u'id': u'126287001', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"CO2 is not pollution."
Pollution is the presence in or introduction into the environment of a substance which has harmful or poisonous effects.
Most harmful or poisonous effects due to substances are dose dependent. Lead levels in the soil of my suburban street are lower than lead levels in the copper/lead ore mining town of Mount Isa. My neighbours' kids can dig in their back yards without risk of poisoning. This is not the case in The Isa where human activities have added much more lead to the soil than they did in my street increasing the levels of lead in parts per million in the soil that kids play in.
The burning of fossil fuels has added more CO2 to the Earth's atmosphere increasing the level of atmospheric CO2 to more than 400 ppm causing an increased greenhouse effect which has so far warmed the global climate by about 1 degree C resulting in climate changes which have been harmful.
Just as the introduction of lead into the environment has been shown to be harmful to growing children in Mount Isa, the introduction of CO2 into the global atmosphere has also been shown to be harmful to people and ecosystems around the globe. Therefore CO2 is a pollutant at its current atmospheric levels and rate of introduction into the environment.
"It might be a greenhouse gas, but it is not pollution."
It is a greenhouse gas. That's a fact, and because it's an effective and long lived greenhouse gas, it has caused harm when introduced into the environment at current levels and its introduction is therefore a form of pollution.
"We put CO2 in fizzy drinks. It hasn't killed anyone yet."
I like to eat Macadamia nuts with my fizzy gin and tonic. These nuts are native to the dry rainforest near where I live. There are four species - M. integrifolia, M. ternifolia, M. tetraphylla and M. jansenii. All four species contain cyanide but the level of cyanide in the first three is too low to be harmful. Not so with M. jansenii, which means you need to know which species you're gathering huts from in the rainforest.
The rate at which my G&T releases CO2 to the atmosphere of the room I'm in is not harmful as it does not raise the level of CO2 in the room to levels which are harmful to me. Nor does it raise the net level of CO2 in the atmosphere as my tonic water manufacturer sourced their CO2 from BOC Gas who removed it from the atmosphere.
However, the burning if fossil fuels has raised the level of CO2 in the atmosphere to a level which is harmful because of the global warming and consequent climate change it has caused. Over 400 ppm CO2 won't directly affect you but 40,000 ppm will cause you physiological distress and over 70,000 ppm will kill you in minutes. Such levels are found in some mines and caves. I once decided not to explore a new cave with CO2 around 30,000 ppm and large loose boulders above a small ravine. I didn't fancy being pinned beneath a boulder in the stream at bottom of the ravine where CO2 was possibly over 40,000 ppm.
The harm caused by pollutants is concentration or dose dependent and CO2 is no exception.
Enjoy your fizzy drink.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1551144060000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'substances', u'effect': u'most harmful or poisonous effects'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'an increased greenhouse effect which has so far warmed the global climate by about 1 degree c resulting in climate changes which have been harmful'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'climate changes which have been harmful'}, {u'cause': u'it', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'the global warming and consequent climate change it has caused', u'effect': u'which is harmful'}, {u'cause': u'over 400 ppm co2', u'effect': u'you physiological distress and over 70,000 ppm will kill you in minutes'}, {u'cause': u'pollutants', u'effect': u'the harm'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'126247298', u'id': u'126286976', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'grahameasom1', u'text': u'I'd like to throw this "per capita" under one of Christian's buses, (which are not gifts, they just haven't been paid for??), and point out that Australia is said to be, per capita, the sixth wealthiest nation in the world.I'm one of those "per capita people", so where's my share?Australia has one of the highest, if not the actual highest,"per capita" emission rate in the world.Me? description: This is not the climate policy solution that the government wants us to thinks it is
og_fields.og:description: This is not the climate policy solution that the government wants us to thinks it is
og_fields.og:title: The emissions reduction fund was deeply flawed – and no rebranding will change this | Tim Baxter
text:
The Coalition government has today released its climate policy for the upcoming election.
Not much could have been expected from the government given that the prime minister has only been in the role six months, and not much was delivered.
There is not a lot of detail around the total package, the $3.5bn cash splash. What we have is enough to make clear that this is not the climate policy solution that the government thinks it is.
The emissions reduction fund is a pool of money that the commonwealth government uses to buy “carbon abatement” from private parties around the country. This carbon abatement occurs when an organisation takes some action to avoid or reduce emissions of greenhouse gases. For instance, a waste company could capture and burn off the methane from its landfills, or a farmer might draw greenhouses gases from out of the atmosphere, by planting trees. At present 26 different methods of abating our emissions are at play under government contracts.
The current funding allocated to the scheme is $2.55bn. About $2.33bn of that money has been allocated to projects already over the ERF’s eight auctions. A little over $480 million has been paid to those running the projects so far.
The government claims that the fund will provide 193 million tonnes of abatement between 2015 and 2028, an average of about 14 million tonnes per year. Those numbers may seem big, but that’s about one third of the emissions per year from Australia’s largest emitter, AGL.
Among a suite of measures announced by the government on Monday was a $2bn boost to the emissions reduction fund, as well as a rebrand. The climate solutions fund will use the same mechanism as the emissions reduction fund and will spend $200m per year over the next 10 years to offset our emissions.
If that funding arrives, and the average price stays the same as recent auctions, that mechanism will deliver approximately 90 million tonnes of abatement in the next decade, with a further 60 million tonnes being delivered after 2030.
That’s a big if. While the government’s headline figure is $2bn, at most only $600m of that will be delivered in the next term of government.
Ignoring the fact that there are many better and more legitimate ways to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions than by direct investment from the government, the ERF fails on its own terms through a series of bespoke issues across the methods.
These have been reported over the past four years and provided a picture of a deeply flawed scheme.
For example, research published by myself and a colleague at Melbourne Law School and reported in the Guardian found that most projects contracted under the ERF’s landfill gas method predate the scheme – some by more than a decade. The fund is supposed to drive new abatement. This is expressly in the goals of the scheme itself. The ERF provides little benefit to the environment by funding these old projects, and the funding is rapidly converted into shareholder dividends.
The revegetation methods while generally robust will be dwarfed by land-clearing elsewhere in Australia. The ERF has secured commitments to deliver 111 million tonnes from revegetation projects across Australia over 2015-2028. Research out of ANU estimates that Australia’s recent land-clearing rates have been releasing up to 38 million tonnes per year. We wouldn’t need to invest this money at all if Australia could get its land-clearing under control.
Another story on Monday revealed that major polluters such as the Granny Smith Gold Mine are being paid by the ERF to switch out one form of fossil fuelled power for another. This is occurring even though the proponents themselves indicated that the funding played no role in their decision to upgrade. Again, this runs counter to the express goals of the fund, which is supposed to drive new emissions abatement opportunities, rather than subsidise project activity that may have occurred anyway.
These problems have pervaded the ERF and will continue into the new climate solutions fund.
Australia is blessed with opportunity when it comes to dealing with climate change. We are the sunniest and windiest inhabited continent in the world, with ample opportunities to build our renewables as well as the necessary infrastructure to support them (such as batteries).
We have incredible potential to reduce our emissions across the country, with analysis released last year from Reputex showing that even Labor’s higher goal of -45% below 2005 levels by 2030 can be reduced on a cost negative basis.
We need to do so much more than accounting tricks and the direct purchase of spurious abatement.
The IPCC’s special report on a 1.5-degree target, released last year made it clear that to have a moderately safe climate, things will be far easier if we start now. The precipitous declines in our emissions that will be needed if we wait until after 2030 are something that I struggle to believe possible.
But if we start now, a relatively safe climate future is achievable. Despite the hyperbole thrown around in certain sectors of the media, and by certain politicians, it is not economy-wrecking, too hard, or not worth it.
More importantly, it is entirely necessary. The world where we choose not to act to prevent the worst of climate change is not looking great.
• Tim Baxter is an associate of the Australian-German Climate and Energy College and a fellow of Melbourne Law School

This graph from a 2017 paper explains it all. It shows the trajectories for cutting ALL CO2 emissions. We do not have much time left to act.
https://www.flickr.com/photos/34386396@N08/42585172890/in/dateposted/
There is a mean budget of 600 gigatonnes (Gt) of carbon dioxide left to emit before the planet warms dangerously, by more than 1.5-2.0 °C. Stretching the budget to 800 Gt buys another 10 years but at a greater risk of exceeding the temperature limit.
If we exceed the 1.5-2.0 °C limit positive feedbacks will very rapidly send the planets temperature to more than 5 °C above current and there is no going back. 
This is the sort of temperatures the Earth had in the Permian Extinction where 95% of all species died 250 million years ago. 
It is not a matter of political ideology. It is a matter of survival.
The majority of known coal, oil and gas reserves MUST stay in the ground. Otherwise it is game over.
If you do not understand this graph then you did not pay attention at school.
We are headed for end of empire stuff folks and there will be nothing left for the barbarian victors as our life support system called Earth will be uninhabitable for most forms of life.
There are millionaires and billionaires buying bunkers that are so called self supporting and underground so that they will be immune to the dystopian future they all know is coming.
They are fools if they think they can ride out a 100,000 year uninhabitable planet.
They have guns and everything to keep out the marauding hordes. I wish them luck with that false hope.
The idiocy and ignorance shown by some contributors here and I use the term loosely is a sight to behold. Do you people go out of your way to prove how stupid you all are? Or are you really that stupid? No need to answer as your pathetic posts convict yourselves.
